text:
Amul has evolved from a dairy to a nutrition brand and is probably the most underrated case study in modern day business. They did a revenue of 90,000cr in FY25. Hard to think of another company in the world that has done something similar. Notes on what i think they got right..

1) They innovate at cooperative speed not startup speed and still wins. Launched 250 product launches in 5 years and that's crazy speed for a cooperative with millions of farmers, 18000+ village societies, and government-linked processes. Most companies will shiver at this speed.

2) They turned cold chain into a moat decades before most startups spoke about supply chain tech. They run India‚Äôs largest cold supply chain with refrigeration networks across rural area and temperature controlled logistics in small towns. This single capability lets them enter any nutrition category quickly.

3) The nutrition transition feels like farmer driven. More milk production means surplus fat & SNF (casien, whey , lactose) and therefore opportunity to create value added products. Every new category like whey, chocolates, drinks, cheese, creates more value for farmers. Most nutrition brands optimise for margins but they optimise for farmer income.

4) Amul is probably the only brand that simultaneously sells mass and premium products all under same brand,  same dairy and distribution and with same trust. Their products range for Rs 5 to 500. Most brands split into sub brands while Amul let the trust carry everything.

No obsession with burn, CAC ,CM1/2 growth and branding. They quietly proved that trust, scale and farmer first thinking can still beat everyone.
comments: So true. Amul didn‚Äôt chase CAC or hype‚Äîthey built distribution, trust, and farmer alignment. That foundation lets them enter any nutrition category almost effortlessly.
Dilip Kumar Appreciate this post wholeheartedly!
¬†Amul quietly built one of India‚Äôs strongest nutrition ecosystems by keeping farmers at the center and distribution as the moat.

Brilliant breakdown. Amul is easily one of the most under-discussed business case studies in the world. They built scale before ‚Äúscale‚Äù became a startup buzzword and did it while staying true to a mission that directly improves farmer income. Hard to think of another brand that balances trust, speed, and purpose so effortlessly.

Amul‚Äôs journey is a reminder that category leadership doesn‚Äôt always need blitzscaling sometimes it comes from compounding trust, farmer-first incentives, and operational depth built over decades.
Amul has mastered and written the blueprint for building everything under one name, so it truly shows up as 'everyone's brand'.

Love this take. Amul is the rare case study where ‚Äúslow‚Äù beats ‚Äúblitzscale.‚Äù They built a cold chain before it was cool, scaled trust instead of CAC, and turned farmer surplus into national nutrition categories.

While startups chase burn and buzzwords, Amul just keeps compounding. Quietly. Consistently. And effortlessly rewriting the playbook.
Congratulations

A local chaat wala in my city bought a 4 cr shop after gaining profit from his Thela, and now his recurring annual revenue is 5cr+ with 70% profit margin

and there are thousands of such vendors throughout the country.

Amul is a reminder that great businesses don‚Äôt need noise to build impact.
What stands out is how they scaled with clarity, trust and long-term thinking, not CAC or burn.  A cooperative launching 250 products in 5 years, running India‚Äôs largest cold chain, and creating a full nutrition ecosystem ‚Äî all while keeping farmers at the centre ‚Äî is an extraordinary achievement.
 
Most companies optimise for margins.  Amul optimises for value creation across the chain ‚Äî farmer, product, distribution and consumer trust.
It‚Äôs rare to see a brand that can play both mass and premium without dilution.  Amul makes it look effortless.
A truly underrated case study in modern business.

This is a fascinating breakdown, and it actually triggers a question I‚Äôve struggled with for months in the cooperative space.
Amul and many state level cooperatives share the same foundational model on paper, farmer owned, federation structure, district unions, democratic boards. Yet the outcomes are dramatically different. Amul achieves alignment, speed, consistency and system driven execution across all its unions, while others with the same architecture often struggle to maintain even basic uniformity in SOPs, decision making or brand strategy.
What I‚Äôve never fully understood is how Amul manages to keep its governance so clean and its processes so harmonized across such a large network. How do they maintain discipline, prevent internal clashes, keep political noise away from operations, and ensure that ‚Äúcooperative‚Äù doesn‚Äôt become an excuse for slow or fragmented decision making?
Would love to understand what cultural or structural guardrails make that kind of consistency possible, because clearly the model is same but the outcomes are worlds apart.
Brilliant breakdown. Amul‚Äôs scale, trust, and farmer-first model show how disciplined innovation can outperform hype. Truly one of India‚Äôs smartest transformations

You have captured so well something I have been marveling for since days Dilip Kumar! To add to that, they have launched some only one in the world - high protein kulfi and others! Amul should have done this long back, but great to see this happening now. #amul should also launch their protein supplement and better infant nutrition products to compete with Nestle, etc. Waiting for it!
This breakdown shows how Amul turned a cooperative structure into a strategic advantage, which of these levers do you think contributed most to their ‚Çπ90,000 crore scale. Dilip Kumar

Dilip Kumar Amul isn‚Äôt just a business case study. It‚Äôs a reminder that when your fundamentals are right distribution, trust, consistency you can outlast every trend.

Completely agree with this. Amul is a phenomenal example of how clarity, trust and infrastructure can beat speed for the sake of speed. It is rare to see a company that can play both mass and premium markets with equal credibility. A true Indian business classic.

One of the first UNICORN and It was set up in 1950‚Äôs with good government support as it was a win win situation for government and co-operative movement and mr Kurian took it to another level ..for any business to grow into UNICORN the first 5 years are the most important break or make years

I'm puzzled how you ignored the cruelty in dairy industry. Here is what you selectively ignored: 
>lifelong confinement of cows and buffaloes, 
>molestation of bulls, 
>artificial insemination of cows and buffaloes, 
>murder of male calves within a few days of their birth, 
>exploitation until the cows or buffaloes fall short of milk, 
>artificial insemination one last time to profit from the extra weight of fetus, 
>transported to slaughter in crammed (5x of animals) trucks,  with chillies in eyes - around 20% of cows and buffaloes deliver calves during transportation, the calves die under their own mothers' legs as their horns are tied up to save space
>finally, slaughtered brutally as they shiver and scream while the fellow cows and buffaloes are slaughtered in front of their own eyes, soaked in blood

Interesting point. I would say that this supply chain moat is pioneered by Pepsi and Coke at a much higher scale across the world who are essentially supply chain companies known by the sugar water brands they peddle. In that sense Amul is the Indian Pepsi.

It's even more incredible how Akshaykalpa is carving a profitable and fast growing niche out of this even with presence of Amul and Nandini. I only prefer buying their Paneer, for e.g. because Amul and Nandini paneers don't really feel soft or fresh. Shashi Kumar and team are doing brilliant work.

It is the beauty of co-operative structure based on which the entire dairy industry operates which is called Amul model wherein village level co op societies affiliated to a district level union which in turn is further federated into a milk federation at state level (GCMMF which markets & distributes it's products under AMUL). Farmers are the backbone of this whole eco system.
At the end of the day whatever the federation earns is passed on to farmers in the form of bonuses and price differences
I find a similar consistency and scalability practice by Prestige. Their cookware is unparalleled in India and abroad (Europe).

Many years ago, when I visited their HQ plant in Anand, I saw that they had a small shop attached to it. I picked up their single origin chocolate there, more than a year ( I think) before they were available in stores. 

They use this shop to test new product lines in a limited capacity, before rolling out a nationwide launch. It's a masterclass on how you can innovate and de-risk at Amul's scale. I'm not at all surprised that they're churning out new products at that speed and winning most of their bets.
Supply chain tech - spot on, they implemented a collection centre for Milk back in my HCL days, and I used to manage that account.

Amul is not just a dairy that scaled but a supply-driven powerhouse that turned millions of farmers and thousands of village societies into a nutrition engine. Their 250-product burst makes sense when you realise their cold chain isn‚Äôt an enabler, it‚Äôs a launchpad. They‚Äôve treated logistics as strategic IP for decades, which is why they can enter any nutrition category almost on demand.
 
What I love most is how every new product‚Äîwhey, cheese, chocolates, drinks‚Äîcomes from smart use of surplus milk solids. It‚Äôs value creation that genuinely raises farmer income, not just margins. Very few ‚Äúnutrition brands‚Äù can claim that.
 
Their single-brand mass-to-premium strategy is another anomaly. Most companies fragment; Amul lets trust do the heavy lifting across ‚Çπ5 to ‚Çπ500 SKUs.
 
Overall, Amul proves something rare today: if your operating system is solid‚Äîcold chain, farmer alignment, and trust‚Äîyou can outrun everyone without shouting about burn or CAC.

Brilliant insights. Amul‚Äôs ability to innovate at scale, despite a cooperative structure is one of the most underrated business feats in India.
The cold chain moat, farmer-driven product expansion, and single brand trust architecture are things even the biggest FMCG players haven‚Äôt cracked.
This post captures exactly why Amul stands in a league of its own.
AMUL - Anand Milk Union Limited from Anand, Gujarat

While everyone else chased margins and marketing, Amul doubled down on trust, cold-chain muscle, and farmer-first economics and that‚Äôs what makes their 90,000+ crore scale feel both inevitable and underrated Dilip Kumar
If there is one thing I didn't like about Amul, the Brand selling "Delicious" a fat spread which looks like butter(misleading consumers at hotels and other places it's used).

The complexity of structured systems is usually seen has hurdles in systems demanding speed. 

As a startup, speed of delivery matters but when done at the cost of inefficiencies or misread consumer expectations , the fundamental damage is already done.  I think the finance world (both institutional and venture funds) need more optimism on structural integrity of young companies over India growth story.

Dilip Kumar, this is such a strong breakdown of a brand we often take for granted. Amul‚Äôs scale looks impressive from the outside, but the real genius is how they built an entire value chain where farmers, supply chain, and consumers all grow together. I‚Äôve always admired how they entered new categories without diluting trust, something even global brands struggle with.
 
Your point about them innovating at cooperative speed really stood out. It proves that when the foundation is solid, speed doesn‚Äôt need to look flashy to be effective.
 
Curious to know which of these strengths you feel will matter the most for them in the next decade

Any business that empowers entrepreneurs will always prosper and create massive societal impact. 

In today‚Äôs age it may be Alibaba for Chinese suppliers or Amazon for global sellers they all fall in the same category. Without Amazon, I wouldn‚Äôt have dreamt of taking my own brand, Lowkal, global. 

Amul did this decades earlier for Indian farmers. Their model shows what happens when an ecosystem is built to genuinely uplift its producers
Show me one other brand that is displayed proudly in both Taj Lands End & the beach opposite in Mumbai! From mass to class, there is only 1 butter!
250 SKUs* at best :)
Their journey shows the power of a brand built on trust.
You can‚Äôt compare Amul to a D2C brand which is new. Dynamics are different, markets are different

Big fan of Amul India and their products. Like every household, our fridge has butter, cheese and maybe the occasional paneer from them. 

But from a business stand point, here's where we are not looking. Amul introduces new products. What has been the adoption of these products? What would be considered a successful metric for each SKU? 
If a food based start-up introduces any new product, there are eagle eyes on them to check adoption, quality, YoY growth etc etc etc. We don't see that with the variety of products Amul brings to market. Atleast I haven't. 

So while Amul can afford to introduce more products, I'd definitely love to see how those products have been lapped up by consumers. What do you think Dilip Kumar?
A brilliant breakdown of Amul‚Äôs playbook‚Äîtrust, scale, farmer-first thinking, and cold-chain mastery. A rare brand that wins through purpose, not burn.
Amul is a masterclass in trust, scale, and farmer-first strategy. Innovation and supply chain excellence make it truly timeless

Heart warming to read this Dilip Kumar. I come from the AUML/IRMA family and have deep respect for small producers and the businesses that respect them. Do read a longer piece written by a dear friend Vaibhav Bhamoriya https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/dr-verghesekurien-inspiring-millions-hundred-years-vaibhav-bhamoriya/

Amul‚Äôs journey always inspires me. Their farmer-first thinking and focus on trust remind me why we‚Äôre building Organi the way we are. Scaling across categories while staying rooted in values is tough, and Amul shows what‚Äôs possible when you get that foundation right.

Amul is a reminder that scale built on trust is still the strongest business strategy in India. What stands out is how they solved fundamentals‚Äîcold chain, farmer economics, and distribution‚Äîlong before these became startup buzzwords. In a landscape obsessed with speed and CAC, Amul shows what long-term value creation actually looks like.

Amul is a great case study for the world. In a world obsessed with CAC, burn, and blitzscaling, Amul is a reminder that trust-led scale is still unbeatable. And sometimes, the most disruptive companies are the ones that don‚Äôt talk about disruption at all.

Amul grows as a ground up cooperative, which took decades to build and a testimony to the socialist experiments which are slow burn but work for India, bring in prosperity all along.

Today we are chasing Bhokaal, Bhandara and IPO models, of course it has brought mayhem to local economies, but as market rationalizes the era of Amuls will come back, it's all 2008 printed dollar which is finding its way around, major devaluation on the way as AI takes foothold, stress on incumbents is already visible.
It‚Äôs always the businesses you don‚Äôt necessarily hear about in your daily life, but are quietly a part of millions of daily lives that make a great business.
This is such a sharp breakdown Amul is truly a masterclass hiding in plain sight.
Amul sells coffee can for both 40 and 90. Same size. And both has buyers.

We‚Äôre building it to help people reconnect with the signals the body sends long before it reaches the point of needing intervention to strengthen immunity, energy, digestion, and calm from the inside out.  Because the most reliable healthcare is still the one we build daily, quietly, consistently through alignment, not dependency.

America just put a $100,000 price tag on the Indian dream. Never been a better time than now for Indian engineers to build at home. The US was the promised land for Indian engineers but not anymore. And India isn‚Äôt the India of the 90s when engineers moved out for better pay and exposure. 

Earlier generations left India because they didn‚Äôt have a choice. Today, staying back is the smarter choice. The US is telling the world that they want fewer immigrants, at higher prices & under tighter conditions. 

In the 1960s & 70s, US actively recruited Indian doctors and engineers to fill shortages. In the 90s & 2000s, IT/software outsourcing made H-1B the obvious path for thousands of engineers. In reality, the India of today is not the India many left behind. 

This is not to say India is without its own constraints. We still have infrastructure gaps and bureaucracy is still frustrating.
But if you look back at history, Indian engineers have always thrived precisely in moments of constraint. 

The outsourcing opportunity of the 90s was born from wage arbitrage. The SaaS opportunity of the 2010s came from building global software with frugal & distributed teams. Each cycle has taken adversity and Indian entrepreneurs turned it into advantage.

The next cycle will be no different. The very inefficiencies of India around fragmented supply chains, healthcare gaps, broken education models will be the anchor to build world class companies. To solve for India is to solve for the future of other emerging markets.

This is the great inversion of our time and for the first time in history, the opportunity cost of leaving India may be greater than the opportunity cost of staying.

The last generation of Indian engineers built America‚Äôs tech backbone. The next generation has the chance to build India‚Äôs. Come back home. Time to build for India and from India.

The truth is, the ‚Äúlast generation of Indian engineers‚Äù didn‚Äôt just build America‚Äôs tech backbone - most of them did so as US citizens or permanent residents, not as Indians building for India. The US offered them world-class infrastructure, compensation, networks, and a chance to rise to global leadership and they took it. That opportunity transformed lives, and it‚Äôs disingenuous to gloss over it now.

Yes, India today is a much stronger place to build than the India of the 90s. Yes, inefficiencies here are real opportunities for entrepreneurs. But let‚Äôs not confuse genuine patriotism with convenient timing. The sudden call to ‚Äústay back and build for India‚Äù comes right after the US has raised the cost of immigration. It feels less like destiny and more like narrative-shaping.

People will always weigh trade-offs. For some, the US will still make sense, for others, India will. Both choices are valid. The point isn‚Äôt to guilt people into staying or leaving, but to build ecosystems in India strong enough that staying truly becomes the better option, not just the cheaper or only one.

Every day I see posts about why people want to leave India. India isn‚Äôt perfect, but no country is. I think before self driving cars or AI chips, we first need to improve quality of life here. 

Imagine if more of us built tools for public good in health & climate that make daily life better. Rainmatter/Zerodha will back and build this together.

What‚Äôs one problem you face daily that you wish had a simple solution?
comments:
I feel one of the best places to put our social investment is in the next generation. Let‚Äôs be honest‚Äîit‚Äôs super hard to change the mindset of people already set in their ways. But kids? They‚Äôre still shaping up, and that‚Äôs where the real impact can be.

Think about it: if we train teachers not just in academics but also in building social awareness, they can pass that on to students in really practical ways. Imagine every school kid‚Äîwhether in a public or private school‚Äîdoing real social projects. Cleaning a lake, helping in old age homes, running an awareness drive‚Äîstuff that actually makes a difference.

And here‚Äôs the twist: what if these projects were graded and ranked, just like math or science? That way, kids start valuing social work as much as academics.

End result? A generation that‚Äôs not just smart, but also socially responsible and empathetic. Honestly, that‚Äôs the kind of future we all need.Dilip Kumar

Love this perspective üôå

Big innovations often grab headlines, but it‚Äôs the everyday frictions that shape how people actually feel about living here.

For me, one simple thing I‚Äôd love solved ‚Üí urban mobility.
 Not just faster cars, but smoother last-mile transport, safer pedestrian paths, and cleaner public transit.

If tech + policy + citizen effort came together here, it would instantly lift quality of life for millions.

Curious to see what everyday problems others point out ‚Äî because solving them might just be the most impactful ‚Äúmoonshots‚Äù we can aim for üöÄ

Dilip Kumar - The real need of the hour is to instill commitment, discipline, ethics, values, and civic sense in schools ‚Äî and to ensure that every citizen not only learns these but also lives by them with consistency and accountability.

I have a solution for the out - of-pocket Healthcare expenses . We need to reverse health insurance .

Right now , Patient > pays insurance company> company decides about reimbursement etc.

What I propose is patient > pays doctor led startup or insurance company > the company will suggest places/hospitals/ service providers. The company not only treats but also plays a role in preventive medicine.
Eg- a young endurance athlete like you will have lesser premium/ subscription than an older person.

This is not being done right now because of the legalities involed. But I am happy to connect and explain the idea more.

Dealing with government processes related to essential needs such as water, electricity, and property management is often challenging. With the recent launch of E-Khata, many property owners who previously had handwritten khatas are facing issues such as spelling errors, incorrect names, or wrong dimensions being recorded.

These errors can cause significant difficulties when someone needs to sell or mortgage their property. Even individuals who purchased property with proper handwritten khatas and valid documentation are now forced to go through unnecessary hurdles in order to utilize their own assets. Unfortunately, this reflects the reality citizens continue to face in our country.

Imagine the greasy leftovers from restaurant kitchens‚Äîoil, fat, bits of food‚Äîall flowing down the drain. That mess gets caught in a special box called a grease trap, which stops it from clogging the city‚Äôs sewer pipes.

But here‚Äôs the problem:  
üß™ Grease trap waste is super messy. It‚Äôs thick, smelly, and full of water, sludge, and food scraps.  
‚öôÔ∏è It‚Äôs hard to clean. You can‚Äôt just scoop out the oil‚Äîit's mixed in with all kinds of gunk.  
üí∏ It‚Äôs expensive to handle. Most people just dump it illegally because cleaning it properly takes time, tech, and money.  
üåç It harms the environment. If it‚Äôs not treated right, it blocks drains, pollutes water, and even causes flooding.

Right after college, our startup was selected for the Bosch Accelerator Program in Koramangala. I lived in Bangalore for about a year - the traffic was hectic but manageable. Then, just days after buying a new OnePlus 5, it was stolen while I was waiting for a cab. The police hinted at a bribe instead of help. For me, that was it.

We moved back to Kochi permanently and only visit Bangalore for meetings. Life here is far better. Like writers need a creative space, founders too need mental and physical room - Kochi gives us that. Yes, we miss the founder -VC camaraderie of Bangalore, but looking back, it feels like the right call for us and for Bangalore. Why add to its congestion when most of the work can be done from here?

VCs have often told us they were more likely to fund us¬†if¬†we moved to Bangalore. But we‚Äôd rather embrace where we are, play to our strengths, and build sustainably than uproot an entire team - their families and vehicles as well - just to add to the saturation. 

Perhaps the solution also lies in fewer people moving to Bangalore unless super critical.

This thought actually comes from my 10-year-old nephew, and it left me amazed at how clearly the next generation sees the challenges we face.
He asked me:
'The speed at which groundwater is running out in so many cities is shocking‚Ä¶ Why can‚Äôt we just collect rainwater on rooftops and redirect used water back into the ground so it doesn‚Äôt run out?'
That simple question captures a massive climate challenge: despite having rainwater harvesting laws and water reuse policies in many states, implementation remains patchy and often ineffective.
Shouldn't we be building tools to make it possible? He wants to create a platform that:
Tracks household water usage in real time
Calculates how much rainwater can be harvested and recharged locally
Provides simple DIY solutions for homes and apartments
Connects communities to adopt water-saving practices collectively
Gamifies conservation so even children feel inspired to participate
Sometimes, it takes the curiosity of a child to remind us that solutions don‚Äôt need to be complicated ‚Äî they just need to be accessible, actionable, and collaborative.

This country seriously needs a centralised live disease outbreak heat map to help authorities and people monitor situations and take targeted actions to improve water, air quality, and the overall environment. Historical data could then track progress over time. People would know what measures the government is taking, while also being more aware of their surroundings and able to take preventive steps. At the same time, the government would know which outbreaks are occurring, how severe they are, and would have the data needed to act quickly.

Such a system can only work if live data is continuously fed into it. That requires prescription filling and lab testing to be digitised and reported in real time by doctors, hospitals, and pharmacies. Building a robust, fully automated system and enforcing it across healthcare providers is a herculean task.

Without this, people will continue to fall sick frequently from water-borne, vector-borne, and airborne diseases.

How serious is this? Dengue outbreaks have become normalised in this country, as if it's a common thing. It's not. The government reports very few cases, however, the numbers are many times higher. Dengue was hardly prevalent 20 years ago.

This needs to be fixed.

It's not just about the imperfection of our country. It's about safety now.

You are walking on the footpath and suddenly you fall in a ditch..rain water accumulates on the road and you are compelled to go on your bike and the bike falls in the ditch or you are walking on flooded road and then you die due to electric shock. Or someone is jealous of you and files a false case against you and makes the false case strong by paying bribe to the police and the case will continue for years.... You will be beaten to death anywhere in the name of caste, religion and language.

So it's now about the safety

We don't have any problems, we are the problem.

We prioritize private transportation (motorbike/car) and are responsible for traffic congestion, air pollution and noise pollution.

We prefer fresh produce (fruits and vegetables) that look good. Therefore, farmers use deadly chemicals to produce spotless vegetables/fruits. We are responsible for soil and water pollution and ecological imbalance.

We always want to succeed and do not see failure as part of learning. We ourselves are responsible for socio-psychological problems.

We prioritize the service industry over agriculture, manufacturing, and research and development. We are responsible for the socio-economic imbalances of the country.

We sell our votes for a few rupees and then criticize politicians and policy makers for the country's stunted development. We are the root cause of corruption.

We are the cause of such endless problems. The best solution to this is for us to change.

text:
Every week, I get a 10 new startup pitches that says ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll deliver healthcare in 10 minutes.‚Äù Quick commerce is now rushing into healthcare. So I thought to do a breakdown on what‚Äôs hype and what might actually work in India. 

What could work?
1)30‚Äì60 min medicine delivery can work for chronic refills or acute needs. In metros with dense demand, it's useful. But 10-min isn‚Äôt necessary. Even same-day is fine for 90% of use cases. And honestly, your local chemist is already doing that.

2) Rapid diagnostics for home blood collection isn‚Äôt about speed but it‚Äôs about hygiene and reliability. A 2-hour sample pickup and next-morning results is a solid win. What we need is better logistics and trained phlebotomists, not faster scooters.

3)On-demand nursing or paramedic visits but for use cases like wound care, IV, injections. Could work with proper scheduling. Think ‚ÄúOla for nurses,‚Äù not ‚ÄúBlinkit for bandages.‚Äù Needs backend infra for verification, training, EMR integration.

What won‚Äôt work (At least not now)
1) Ambulance in 10 mins sounds great until you hit Delhi or Bangalore traffic. Speed is useless without triage and location accuracy. What we really need is better coordination between hospitals and ambulance providers, not just faster wheels.

2) On-demand doctors in 10 mins is a bad idea. You don‚Äôt need any doctor fast but you need the right one. Discovery & matching are bigger problems than speed. Most video consults struggle with quality, not timing. Clinical care isn‚Äôt fast food. Trust takes time.

3) The 10-min everything app for healthcare is lazy ambition dressed up with VC money. Healthcare isn‚Äôt a SKU game but it‚Äôs complex, regulated, and hard to standardize like groceries. Great for funding buzz, terrible for trust and real outcomes.

Few thoughts if you really are passionate to build in healthcare. 
Trust > velocity.
Speed isn‚Äôt everything.
Infra & people ops > APIs.
Reliability > 10-min hacks.
Health is longitudinal & not transactional.

Good luck if you're building something in Healthcare in India.
comments: Very insightful, particularly about sample collection and doctors, a good diagnosis and doctor after 2 days is anyday better than a doctor in 10 mins. If quick consultations were needed then second opinions would not have existed, it‚Äôs about one‚Äôs life afterall

Good one. Speed can be a moat in healthcare, but it is not enough. It only matters when backed by reliability, credibility, and clinical accuracy. Without that, it is just fast delivery of poor outcomes Dilip Kumar

The point about hygiene and reliability is so valid. Some companies rush reports, but after talking to a few doctors, I realised they don‚Äôt trust them because many results have been inaccurate.

So doctors often retest everything just to be safe.

In my opinion, building for healthcare in India has to be closely aligned with how primary care providers aka doctors operate.

Healthcare isn‚Äôt a SKU. 10-min apps ignore what truly matters: care quality, compliance, and patient trust. We need to shift from speed obsession to well-being obsession. The future of healthcare isn‚Äôt ‚Äúfaster everything‚Äù, it‚Äôs smarter, safer, and more human.
Devika Bhatia Ojaswini Bansal

The best "10-minute" healthcare would be an ALS Ambulance connected to a Command center where a dedicated or a clan of ER Physicians could triage asap. This will also ensure the patient is getting the optimum care even when stuck in traffic.

Loved this, Dilip. While the 10-min-fix fad grabs headlines, the real challenge in Bharat is access to qualified doctors, not just speed. At #ZiffyHealth, we're going beyond the buzz ‚Äî building #eclinics and #telehealth infra that actually reach the rural and semi-urban population. It's slow, gritty, and full of learning ‚Äî but we‚Äôre here to solve real problems.

üí° Great insight
 You've captured a deep truth about healthcare startups‚Äîcommendable insight.
Healthcare isn't a fast-moving consumer sector; it demands precision, trust, and long-term infrastructure. We‚Äôre in the same space, working on this exact challenge. But unfortunately, many investors don‚Äôt yet see the vision‚Äîso we've chosen the path of bootstrapping.

MedMEU is India‚Äôs first truly integrated healthtech platform‚Äîfrom blood test booking for patients to lab software, logistics, and support for diagnostic centers.
We don‚Äôt just connect‚Äîwe enable the entire ecosystem.

Our business model isn‚Äôt built for hype. It‚Äôs built for resilience.
And we‚Äôre confident‚Äîour impact will speak louder than any pitch.
Deeply insightful!

This 10 min healthcare delivery is just the thing we are doing since last 2 years at The Society Clinic 

And our outcomes are

1) healthcare is 24*7 job so don't go for zepto or blinkit kind of approach of morning to night, it will dilute the purpose,

2) the thing one need in or below 10 mins is primary care or emergency care, when you need dressing or injection support for stone pain/dog bite you need it immediately. In case of emergency you just need right support before ambulance arrives

3) for any preventive need you need quality and right guidance and not the speed,

4) for doctor consultation physical delivery is all times not possible or practically possible, but you need right technology to have right doctor support

5) technology is enabler here and not the core because AI will not give injection or do dressing, you need quality people, but yes good technology or AI will smoothen the processes,

Few of my observations:

1. Medicine Delivery has active players, but profitability is a myth. The SKU mix is complex, and full prescriptions are rarely available. If customers still need to step out to complete their purchase, the convenience breaks down.

2. Scheduled Drugs need prescriptions, but there‚Äôs no real gatekeeping. Anyone can upload a prescription, there‚Äôs little to no verification (last I used). In theory, even a kid could order sleeping pills. Plus, some essential drugs aren‚Äôt deliverable, adding more friction.

3. Online doctor consults are broken. Diagnosis quality is hit or miss. Often, it‚Äôs junior doctors and patients spam chats, making it impossible to justify doctor costs. It just becomes unsustainable.

4. Healthcare is inherently trust-based. When people are spending money on health, they choose trust not the apps. That's why hospitals and local practitioners still win.

Lastly, healthcare is largely a grey-area and practitioners do not want to loose that control.

Striking that balance‚Äî‚ÄúOla for nurses,‚Äù not ‚ÄúBlinkit for bandages‚Äù‚Äîcould be the foundation of a sustainable healthcare play in India.

Dilip Kumar This is one of the most grounded takes I‚Äôve seen on healthcare x speed in India. We‚Äôre building Vitalyzer‚Ñ¢ with the same mindset not chasing 10-minute gimmicks, but focusing on accuracy, hygiene, and trust in diagnostics. Speed without reliability is dangerous in health. The challenge isn‚Äôt delivering fast it‚Äôs delivering right.
Curious: what kind of infra do you think still needs to be built if we‚Äôre serious about scaling this responsibly across Tier 2 & 3 cities?

Great breakdown. A few complementary thoughts that might be worth layering in:
‚Ä¢ Care navigation ‚Äì Access is one part, but helping patients know what to do next is often where real value lies. Especially important in chronic and post-acute care.
‚Ä¢ Clinical accountability at the last mile ‚Äì Whether it‚Äôs a home nurse or a teleconsult, accountability and escalation protocols are often underdeveloped in speed-first models.
‚Ä¢ Health data interoperability ‚Äì Without some form of continuity in records, faster care can actually increase risk. Building with safety nets matters more than timelines.

A 10-minute service might be fine for a simple issue, but it‚Äôs risky if it becomes the norm for more complex cases. 

Health is multifaceted, and some problems require more than just a quick fix. They need deeper investigation, long-term care, and ongoing support. 

A quick diagnosis leading to Superficial treatment carries the risk of missing underlying issues due to lack of time or thorough examination. Plus, it could lead to a greater reliance on technology and less emphasis on the doctor-patient relationship, which is vital for trust and comprehensive care.

I completely agree with your insights. At Just What Works, while we‚Äôre (I and Nikhil Khurana, PhD)  not delivering in 10 minutes, we're focused on minimalism in our products, ensuring they meet essential human needs effectively.
Ah yes, because nothing says ‚Äútrust‚Äù like a doctor who‚Äôs just a click away and probably on a scooter!

Absolutely loved this breakdown. In healthcare, trust compounds, not delivery speed. The real opportunity lies in reimagining care infrastructure, not just timelines. We‚Äôre seeing it firsthand in how simulation-based training is redefining learning outcomes in surgical education. Health isn‚Äôt about ‚Äúinstant,‚Äù it‚Äôs about ‚Äúimpact.‚Äù Let‚Äôs build for that.

- Let‚Äôs not forget ‚Äî no one ‚Äúneeded‚Äù 10-min groceries either, until suddenly bananas became more urgent than broadband.

- Urban consumption has a way of turning absurdities into expectations.

- True, 90% of healthcare doesn‚Äôt need speed. But for the 10% that does ‚Äî emergency meds, critical blood tests, or that dreaded 7AM fasting sample ‚Äî speed becomes habit-forming convenience.

-At Zet Health, we‚Äôve learned that trust is the baseline, not a differentiator. But speed isn‚Äôt evil ‚Äî it just needs solid infra: trained staff, reliable logistics, and clinical protocols.

-So before we throw speed-focused healthcare under the ambulance, let‚Äôs remember ‚Äî 10% of lives improved is still impact.

I enjoyed reading the post, and someone had to say it. Through my experience, I've learned that people don't want fast healthcare instead, they want accessible healthcare that actually works.

I've watched people chase quick fixes for months, only to find lasting change when they commit to longer-term relationships with practitioners who understand their patterns.

The real gaps I see:
-Finding the right practitioner, not just any available one
-Building trust over time, not rushing consultations
-Integrating mind-body approaches that require patience
-Creating continuity of care, not episodic band-aids

Speed optimizes for convenience. Healthcare optimizes for outcomes. The best healing happens when someone feels truly seen and understood - that takes time, not technology.

That‚Äôs what makes healthcare delivery fundamentally different from any other form of quick commerce.

There are genuine clinical scenarios like Arterial Blood Gas tests  where 10-minute collections are not a luxury, but a necessity.

When the quality, price, and trust remain consistent, but one option delivers faster the choice is clear. Consumers are evolving, and so are their expectations. Quick commerce is the new normal !

Dilip Kumar Where can I actually have a proper chat with you?

I‚Äôve tried reaching out, but I always get the same reply: "It‚Äôs too early for us", even from your team. 

No one really asked how I plan to execute my idea or what kind of support you could offer.

I understand that money is important but when I said I needed funding only, even moral or strategic support can really motivate entrepreneurs like me. People like us, who don‚Äôt have a strong network or ‚Äúcircle,‚Äù often feel stuck.

In India, we‚Äôre often afraid to take risks, yet we expect our country to perform like the US or China and in reality, we‚Äôre still competing with countries like Pakistan, Bangladesh, or the Maldives because of politics and a weak business ecosystem.

Got a message yesterday from a friend that they lost their 7 day old baby last week. Got me thinking why this happens and turns out, it‚Äôs not uncommon.

India‚Äôs infant mortality rate is about 25 per 1,000 births. That‚Äôs 2.5% of infants who don‚Äôt survive. The sad part is that nearly 60% of these deaths are preventable with better care. 

This is where I believe AI in healthcare can truly make a difference. 
We can develop predictive models for at-risk pregnancies using maternal health data. Build remote monitoring systems that flag early signs of preterm labor. Even use image based diagnostics to catch neonatal infections before they turn fatal.

I hope more people building for healthcare in India focus on solutions that can detect risks early and save lives. No parent should lose a child to something we could‚Äôve seen coming.

This resonates deeply. I'm sorry for your friend's loss - losing a child is unimaginable.
You're absolutely right about the AI potential in healthcare, and I think the scope is even broader than the 2.5% post-birth mortality you mentioned.
Looking at the complete picture in India: out of every 1,000 pregnancies, roughly 169 don't result in a healthy baby surviving the first year. This includes ~100 miscarriages, ~26 stillbirths, and ~43 infant deaths. That's nearly 17% of all pregnancies.
What's particularly heartbreaking is how unprepared couples are for this reality. Most don't realize that pregnancy loss is this common, so when it happens, they're not just grieving - they're also completely blindsided and often blame themselves.

An even bigger problem is maternal mortality,and the two factors are linked.
Childbirth and pregnancy are not classified as a disease under insurance yet so many lives are lost for no reason at all.

Yes, you are right. But this issue is severe in the rural areas. Even if AI is capable, penetrating the rural layers is a huge challenge. We still have a severe shortage of skilled nurses and neonatologists.

Rationale isn‚Äôt based in reality. Healthcare system isn‚Äôt broken in detection, it is rigged in intent designed to loot. Doctors and hospitals are practicing financial triage. The SOPs and facilities are also far inferior than western and eastern counterparts. Much if that can be fixed.

Neonatal mortality remains significantly higher in rural India (~1.5x urban). While national rates have dropped to ~25/1,000 live births (2021 numbers). The urban numbers are not that drastic, but still alarming. It also shows variations in states etc, like in urban karnataka it is 8/1000. Neonatal deaths occur many times due to sepsis which is preventable by rigorous hygeine at hospital and home. While the urban areas have better private sector hospitals, rural areas mainly depend on government infrastructure which is deplorable in many states. Many NGOs are working on this part, teaching hygeine to parents and working on best practices in hospitals. Predictive power of death from sepsis in Neonates are high with guidelines available which doctors are aware of. 
So, I believe that neonatal mortality can be better prevented from best practices and pure hygeine , handwashing rather than AI models. More than that, the real place of need is rural india where penetration of basic technology is pretty low.
Just my thoughts as a subject matter person!

Dr Abhay Bang and Dr Rani Bang have worked in this area for last few decades in Gadchiroli district of Maharashtra.¬†

Heartbreaking ‚Äî and so important that you brought this to light, Dilip Kumar

The numbers are painful, but what‚Äôs worse is how¬†avoidable¬†many of these tragedies are. When 60% of infant deaths are preventable, it‚Äôs not just a statistic ‚Äî it‚Äôs a call to action.

AI has real potential here: not to replace care, but to¬†extend its reach¬†‚Äî especially in areas where infrastructure is thin. From early risk stratification to remote diagnostics, the tech already exists. What‚Äôs missing is deployment at scale, and the will to prioritize it.

There‚Äôs so much talent in India‚Äôs healthtech space. Hopefully this post nudges more of it toward problems that truly matter.

Predictive models will need a large data set of longitudinal data: actual patient histories and real life events/outcomes, instead of established theories. Unfortunately this may be difficult as maternal healthcare is highly fragmented>getting continuous, reliable data may be a huge challenge> it easily gets lost out of the loop due to variety of reasons....preventive care is a sore thumb in AI.  I'd love to know your thoughts!

Absolutely resonated with this. Having spent the last 20 years evaluating innovations, patents, and emerging tech (large part of my work has been in health tech), I can say that predictive models, AI diagnostics, remote monitoring, and historical health data modeling do have great potential to improve outcomes. But I think the biggest challenges are not due to the absence of such technologies particularly in Indian context. In fact, in many cases the risk is already known to doctors, to health workers, sometimes even to the family. Yet the tragedy still unfolds. Because of gaps in awareness, social and behavioral factors, resource limitations, infrastructure constraints, and lack of action for some other reasons. These are systemic, not technological, barriers. That said, technology must still be built, and smartly. Not just to predict, but to integrate meaningfully into care pathways .
Dr. Shantanu Pathak - Thought of Doto's solution on reading the post.

We have massive amounts of medical data across hospitals and clinics in India that lie unused. The big challenge is in building systems to collect and organise this data. If we can, the potential is huge. 

Rahul Gandhi talked about working on this in his 2019 campaigns but no real progress has been made by anyone in this area yet as far as I know.

Heartbreaking to read this and yet so important that we talk about it.
You're right, the potential of AI in maternal and neonatal care is massive. Early detection, personalized risk profiling, and faster intervention can truly move the needle.
Thank you for spotlighting this with the urgency it deserves.

Our company launched the Premier Badminton League, which we managed for five years until the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite featuring talented players like PV Sindhu, Saina Nehwal, Kidambi Srikanth, Lakshya Sen, Satwik-Chirag, and others, we struggled to attract big-name supporters. Some celebrities, including Akshay Kumar and SRT who initially backed the league, eventually exited. We also reached out to another legend multiple times, but he only made a brief appearance in Season 5 without promoting the league.

Every season, we invited the Union Sports Minister to attend the inaugural match or finals, but he never attended. Even India's historic Thomas Cup win in 2022 didn't translate to increased support for badminton. Despite brainstorming with legendary coach Pullela Gopichand, we couldn't raise the sport's profile as we'd hoped. Although participation in the game increased significantly during this period, we ultimately couldn't achieve our goals and had to discontinue the league.

It's disheartening that as a nation, we often overlook our true heroes.

The issue of adulterated milk is concerning, but a more significant concern is the rising prevalence of lactose intolerance. Lactose is a naturally occurring sugar found in milk and other dairy products. When individuals are lactose intolerant, their bodies are unable to digest this sugar due to a deficiency of the enzyme lactase, leading to uncomfortable symptoms.

Given the existing high rates of lactose intolerance in India, estimated to be over 60% according to various studies, it's likely that many will seek dairy alternatives. The growing awareness of lactose intolerance is expected to drive interest in plant-based milk options, providing a potential solution for those looking to manage their dietary needs.

Any consumer can choose to test their sample  occasionally for a cost (cheaper than buying and managing a home device). This can change the behavior of the offenders by making contamination harder to keep up with and more tranparent within society. Spread awareness of the importance of random testing and make testing labs available regionally. This can also be expanded to other food products that may fall in this category of risk. This kind of private testing might be an antidote to lack of centralized regulatory efforts by the government to address these issues.

With you on that one! One must also consider the fact that the modes and adulterants themselves may keep changing. Till early 2000's, it was more of traditional adulteration where people were more worried about simpler problems like "is there water mixed in this milk?". Of course synthetic milk existed, but wasn't as looming a menace. The following period till 2012, saw the rise of synthetic adulterants like hydrogen peroxide, formalin, and other nasties. Thereafter, with stringent crackdown by the apex body, adulteration shifted towards micro level localized infusions whereby tests had to be far more sensitive to detect the same when a small batch of adulterated milk was mixed with a larger quantity of milk. While consumer awareness is steadily on a rise, much to our delight, the makers of such kits must look at tackling 2 things continuously:
(1) Stay abreast with any never-seen-before malpractices and create tests for them
(2) Keep the users (read, consumers) continuously updated and aware of such changes

Doctors in India die earlier than their patients. I know it sounds crude but what it means is Indian doctors have a life expectancy that‚Äôs nearly 10 years shorter than the average Indian. And this is reported by Indian Medical Association. 

The primary causes are Cardiovascular disease and infections. Ironically, the very things they work tirelessly to prevent.

Endure 10-12 years of medical education with the only aspiration to save lives but be at the receiving end of stress, anxiety, and long working hours. And be a part of a system that doesn‚Äôt give them time to care for their own health. The average Indian doctor clocks 60‚Äì80 hours a week and approx 300-400 doctors die by suicide every year. Mostly because of the impossible expectations they carry. It takes 10+ years of study before a doctor sees their first salary.

They‚Äôre taught that saving lives is everything. After 10hrs+ of work, you can then go and figure your own personal health & family life. And after all this, they‚Äôre now told that AI will make them obsolete. That their jobs will be replaced by software tools because the system is inefficient.

I meet atleast 50 companies a month that pitch AI solutions for healthcare. These tools matter and they can make processes faster and improve accessibility. No doubt Indian healthcare needs better processes and better tech. But what it needs more than anything is empathy.

India‚Äôs hospitals are crowded and the health crisis is real. But what‚Äôs also been ignored is the mental and physical health of our doctors & medical staff. 

This isn‚Äôt a rant against technology, AI or healthcare system. But a reminder to self and maybe a few who are reading this that without empathy and without recognizing the human cost, there will be no healthcare system left.
comments: Powerful reminder that healing isn‚Äôt just about better tech, it‚Äôs about better treatment of those who heal us. Empathy isn‚Äôt optional in healthcare; it‚Äôs foundational.

Dilip Kumar The reduced life expectancy of doctors compared to their patients in India stems from the belief that longer training periods and rigorous filtering alone can ensure the development of quality healthcare providers to address the country‚Äôs massive healthcare crisis. However, this approach often worsens the situation by overburdening the system and negatively impacting doctors' quality of life, contributing to their shorter lifespans. Constantly requiring doctors to clear multiple competency exams does little to improve care and, in the worst-case scenario, adds strain to an already overstretched healthcare system. To address this, India must reform its medical education by promoting collaborative and shared care delivery across various levels, and by recognizing that extending doctors' life expectancy by even a decade would have a more meaningful impact than simply increasing the number of medical seats, only to force new doctors into an already broken system.

Dilip Kumar, you‚Äôre right. India‚Äôs doctors aren‚Äôt just dying early‚Äîthey‚Äôre being systemically failed. But history shows us that even the most entrenched crises can be reversed with political will and collective action. Here‚Äôs how we can turn this around:

Global playbook India must adopt now:
Work-Hour Reform
 US caps at 80 hrs/week, EU at 48 hrs/week. India? 100+ hours with no regulation.
  Fix: Amend the Factories Act to include healthcare.
Mental Health Support
 US/UK offer confidential, anonymous therapy. 
India? Stigma + no access.
  Fix: 1 counsellor per 100 beds via state schemes.
Violence Protection
 Australia has panic buttons, & Canada runs ‚ÄúCode White.‚Äù
 India? Silence.
  Fix: Enforce ‚ÄúCode Silver‚Äù + fast-track courts.
Admin Relief
 Scandinavia uses AI; Germany mandates scribes.
 India? 30% of doctors' time is lost to paperwork.
 Fix: Subsidise AI scribes under Ayushman Bharat.
Training Reform
 The US & the Netherlands teach emotional resilience. India? Rote learning.
  Fix: Upgrade AETCOM with mandatory wellness modules.
Wellness Incentives
 The US pays stipends, & France adds 20% pay for stress roles.
 India? No incentive.
  Fix: Link pay to burnout zones + wellness metrics.
This isn‚Äôt charity; it‚Äôs economic survival.

So far we have seen the evidence that the 20‚Äôs is the new 40‚Äôs and surprisingly 40‚Äôs are better aware than 20‚Äôs.

Thanks for your concern.  I can site a few remedies for this .
1. Stop having impractical expectations from the treatment . Social media false claims and faux advertisements  by private hospitals add fuel to this expectations. 
2. Do not try to treat your doctor as God,  he has no magic power . He is like other professionals who helps you when you are in trouble.
3. Trust your doctor fully ,but if you have slightest of doubt move on. A doctor has a peaceful mind  when he finds that the patient trusts him fully.
4. Do not judge a doctor by the sheer number of Google reviews or presence of patients in the waiting area. You can buy those.
There is a difference between a good doctor and a famous doctor that you will have to judge.
5. Take active part in the decision making by your doctor.
6.All these will help the doctor to go for defensive medicine at your own cost.

For the doctors  - To some of us it appears that there is no tomorrow. We forget that the doctors are responsible for their families and more importantly their own health.
Peer pressure to own an expensive flat or a car or face book publications for exotic holiday pics doesn't yield patients. It is the time given to them  with a  little honesty that matter most.

Greater participation of doctors & nurses in the making of healthcare AI, so that realistic pain points concerning Drs & nurses who are at 'ground zero' & actually take the hits are actively worked upon & resolved...not just AI designs made soley in Offices !!
Newer crop of doctors are well aware of this. They either leave the country or leave medical practice earlier. Yeah a few cant afford either would die earlier probably than their patients.
Also, the pay is peanuts for the first 5-10 years after the first 10 years of intense education.
Such a thoughtful post! A good reminder that while technology is important, the human touch in healthcare is truly irreplaceable.
Thank you for calling this out, Dilip!
Most surgeons I know are also smokers, the high stress, odd working hours only adding to the outcome. Empathise is the least we can do, after them working tirelessly for hours at times.

This one is an eye opener Dilip.

I would go to a skilled doctor using AI, than the hospitals that are completely running on AI.
Because it's the empathy and the human touch that makes traversing critical health conditions better. Not just precise tech solutions.

And I have personally seen my doctor friends leave everything and tirelessly work for days without break. And wonder how can a system be built to ensure they focus on their health too‚ÄîA problem statement that actually needs tech or system intervention, in my opinion.
Doctors need healing too.

AI won't make doctors obsolete anytime soon; if anything, doctors will now have one more task of navigating around AI learned patients. 
First the softwares that added clicks but did little to improve patient care, and now AI, that will very confidently misguide the patients with a disclaimer shrugging off the responsibility. 
This piece is a reality check for those building patient facing LLM powered tools: https://amirkiani.xyz/posts/yari-care-nav/

Dilip Kumar Absolutely, the medical fraternity puts so much of time and effort into working towards people‚Äôs better health. 
An important point, It boils down to supply and demand Biomedicine unlike the Tech space needs a long time in training. No other domain grew in so much of understanding over the last few decades as Biomedical Sciences.  So there is a huge shortage in the number of people who get trained. An other extremely ignored domain in biomedical Scientists and researchers who contributed to the development. They equally toil for 12-15hrs a day with very poor outcomes, as they are mostly invisible to society.  
This is nothing to do with lacking empathy for clinicians. The point to raise the thought of the entire community who contribute to betterment of health!

This hit hard. Behind every white coat is a human carrying silent exhaustion. We talk about saving lives, but forget those who do the saving need saving too. More care, more empathy‚Äînot just for patients, but for our doctors. üôè

I am glad you raised the concern. I have massive respect for the profession, but my heart breaks when I see how hectic their schedule is. Literally, some interns are working for 24+ hour shifts at a stretch :(
Mental health , the next big crisis , the next big opportunity .

If the doctors are overburdened and takes 10-12 years of studies, I guess AI will help them to shorten the procedure of both studies and treatment. 

AI will be an aid to healthcare, we will still need experts to run them.
The dedication doctors show despite everything stacked against them is beyond inspiring. We owe them so much more than just gratitude.

If you think its because of #people or politics or inaccurate tools to judge a problem or time taking clinical reports?

We are helping Doctors to generate medical reports from Xrays in matter of seconds, there by creating Gold Standards of accuracy in detecting disease  and that too immediately. Thereby no wastage of time and early detection reduce the chance of delay in writing prescriptions.

Interested to know how it's changing the landscaping of rural upliftment?

This may be anecdotal, but I've found most doctors ignore their own advice, a lot of them smoke and drink, and I suspect they may feel disassociated and apathetic about their own future disease if they see disease and death every day.

We need more Doctors.
We also need AI to help them reduce their Stress and working hours.

Both are true at the same time...

Doctors are stressed specially in the public health facilities and tech can definitely offload the pressure. AI to be successful in public health systems in my exp would need certain considerations - preparedness and adaptability of the system and manpower itself, more so tech to be customised for the system. Some wonderful soltutions don‚Äôt scale and sustain beyond the pilot phase as these two key aspects are ignored.
Efficiency without empathy is dangerous. Tools must support doctors, not replace their humanity.

They also have a much higher prevalence of diabetes and other lifestyle disorders than regular people. Surprisingly high number of smokers and drinkers, much above than country‚Äôs average. 

Ref 

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/281449079_Prevalence_of_Diabetes_Hypertension_and_Obesity_among_Doctors_and_Nurses_in_a_Medical_College_Hospital_in_Tamil_Nadu_India

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/39317936/

https://www.msjonline.org/index.php/ijrms/article/view/2345

https://www.mdpi.com/1660-4601/11/1/429

https://www.medicalandresearch.com/current_issue/1654

Mental Health of doctors is also generally very poor, often overburdened but also greatly isolated. Unlike other professions say Bankers who work with each other, Doctors particularly running their own clinics barely interact with their own colleagues/classmates/friends leading to further isolation.

We had a family doctor uncle (my parents' friend) from Sir Sundar Lal - Lucknow, undoubtedly a high achieving genius with extreme detail to attention, who saw our entire family for some 35 odd years; who died couple years ago at age 63. Towards last decade of his life, he has become increasingly lonely, isolated, separated from his wife, chain smoker, and drowned himself in work and books - yet lonely amid the crowd of nurses, compounders and patients. 

Signs of this loneliness and isolation and lack of friends/community around doctors can be seen in mid 40s, as soon as they get more senior and move out from Hospital job system to their own clinic system. 

Sometimes, I deduce, friends and community is the highest life extending agent, ahead of nutrition, exercise and everything else.

text:
An advice from one entrepreneur to another thinking to become a founder today. Manifest this reality-it‚Äôs going to be hard. Harder than you imagine. Blogs and YouTube videos are designed to make you feel good. They‚Äôre useful, but they‚Äôre mostly made by people who seen some form of success. Don‚Äôt start thinking there‚Äôs a single linear path. The journey will be be scary and lonely.

Take care of your health, both physical and mental. Walk, run, meditate, lift, cycle, swim. Just do anything. Don‚Äôt wait for a crisis. There‚Äôs no pivot for your body.

Don‚Äôt take your relationships for granted. You think they‚Äôll wait, but they won‚Äôt. And they shouldn't.  Everyone has finite time to build a life. You‚Äôre not wealthy if you have no one to share it with.

Lastly, don‚Äôt chase status. It‚Äôs the surest way to damage your joy and clarity. Every mistake is an opportunity to improvise. Get good at being corrected without being offended. The rest will follow if you build from a place of authenticity and love for the craft.

No YouTube video or blog can prep you for the real grind. It‚Äôs lonely, exhausting, and at times, just plain confusing.
That line ‚Äî ‚Äúthere‚Äôs no pivot for your body‚Äù ‚Äî really stayed with me.
Health, people, purpose. Easy to overlook, but so important.
Grateful you shared this.
Keep moving - one step at a time!

 üß† How to separate your worth from your revenue

 üíõ How to build without betraying yourself

This is the kind of honest advice more aspiring founders need to hear‚Äîespecially the part about health and relationships. Hustle culture glorifies burnout, but what‚Äôs the point of building an empire if your body‚Äôs broken and you‚Äôre alone at the top? Bookmarking this for every time I need to realign with what actually matters

Powerful and real advice, Dilip! üôå The startup journey is definitely not glamorous ‚Äî it‚Äôs tough, unpredictable, and often lonely. Prioritizing health and relationships alongside hustle is what truly sustains long-term success.
This needs to be printed, framed, and slapped on every founder‚Äôs wall.
¬†Prioritizing health and relationships isn‚Äôt just self-care; it‚Äôs foundational for sustainable success.¬†
Thanks Dilip Kumar . Amazing advice.
This hit hard. As a founder, it‚Äôs easy to lose perspective when stakes are high. But this reminder about detaching ego from outcome is gold‚Äîhumility is what keeps long-term builders in the game.
Excellent advice üëè.. i guess every entrepreneur resonates to each world of this..

This truly resonates with me as someone navigating my own path. The romanticized versions of entrepreneurship rarely show the grit, loneliness, and relentless challenges behind the scenes. Taking care of our mental and physical health isn‚Äôt just self-care‚Äîit‚Äôs survival for the long haul. And the reminder about relationships hits home: success feels empty without people to share it with. Authenticity and love for the work are indeed the only true compass through the uncertainty. Grateful for this ‚Äîit‚Äôs the kind of wisdom every aspiring founder needs to hear.
Dilip Kumar, thanks for writing this. In a world where hustle culture is celebrated, people need to hear this.

You're so right about taking care of health‚ÄîI've been guilty of neglecting it, and it really does catch up with you. Thanks for the reminder to prioritize it Dilip Kumar

Dilip Kumar

Excellent advice! Building from authenticity - intrinsic motivation - is good for your health, and good for the people who experience your output.

Build from clarity, not chaos. From craft, not status. From love, not FOMO. This is the most honest advice I‚Äôve read in a while.
Dilip Kumar Every line here hits hard. Building something real takes more than vision, it takes resilience, humility, and heart.

One of the things I've realised over the years as an entrepreneur is that most people (almost 99%) underestimate the amount of work it takes to achieve sustainability and profitability. And this same set of people highly overestimate the quality of life.

 It‚Äôs not for the average person ‚Äî and that‚Äôs okay.

text:
Every investor wants to back a disruptive startup that can make money. India sees 50,000+ new startups a year. And every founder gets asked the same question- What‚Äôs new in what you‚Äôre building? 

Maybe it‚Äôs time founders asked VCs the same. What‚Äôs new in your fund? What edge do you bring that a thousand others don‚Äôt?

People often ask why we cheer and share about startups we haven‚Äôt invested in. It‚Äôs because we are not just investors, we‚Äôre here to build ecosystems. And India needs that now. 

Most VCs love to talk about their portfolio. But the reality is, market doesn‚Äôt reward portfolios. It rewards categories. And in India, we need large movements along with unicorn outcomes. 

At Rainmatter, I‚Äôve seen hot deals been let got :). We‚Äôve never played the status game.¬†We support founders and even their competitors, if it helps grow the category and the narrative. When more people understand health, money, and climate and more builders create solutions-everyone wins

Btw, we do podcast with founders we didn‚Äôt fund :). I share our observations and learnings openly from our portfolio companies. 

There are 2000 VC funds in India. I'm hoping some of them starts thinking beyond the old Silicon Valley VC model.
comments: What‚Äôs new in your fund?¬†Dilip Kumar üòá

This is the kind of VC mindset India desperately needs‚Äîless gatekeeping, more category building. 
Founders are rewriting the rules, and it's time investors did too. 
Backing the ecosystem, not just equity, is what creates real, lasting change. 
Playing the long game isn‚Äôt old-school‚Äîit‚Äôs visionary

The problem with 2000 funds is that it is too much money chasing too few venture fundable deals. Startups that should not be funded are getting funded. Extreme pressure is being put on them to grow at venture scale. And then, between 2023 and 2024, 28,000 startups have shut down. If they bootstrapped, focused on steady customer development and providing real value, iterated through the inevitable market challenges, there would not be so many deaths.

Too many startups that should be bootstrapped are raising VC money.
Emergence of new age fund that offers much more that just capital is what the founders will look for in future. It  will be first individual movement then institution will follow on.

Your perspective on fostering a collaborative ecosystem in India is truly inspiring, Dilip. Supporting founders across the board and focusing on category growth rather than just portfolio bragging is a refreshing approach that will undoubtedly lead to richer innovation. Keep championing this mindset!

BUSINESS CLASS FOR EVERYONE
Hi Dilip,
I‚Äôm building‚Äî a new Indian airline that‚Äôs going 100% business class at near-economy fares., 

We‚Äôre not tweaking the system ‚Äî we‚Äôre replacing it.
Imagine Indigo meets Emirates ‚Äî flat beds, gourmet meals, premium experience ‚Äî but built for the Indian mass flyer, not just the 1%.
one mission:
Make business class the new economy.
I know you‚Äôve seen bold ideas before. But I don‚Äôt think you‚Äôve seen this one.
Would love 5 minutes to show you why this isn‚Äôt just another startup ‚Äî it‚Äôs the next transport revolution out of India.
Regards,
Ansh Thakral
https://www.trasil.in/

Dilip Kumar Love the idea of flipping the script‚Äîfounders asking VCs what *they're* bringing to the table. Feels like that kind of transparency could push the whole ecosystem forward. Imagine if more funds shared openly like this...it‚Äôd shift how categories grow.

Completely agree, investors need to think beyond innovation as every start can't be  innovative especially building market segments, one player cannot serve the whole purpose, multiple players in the same space will benefit customers & startups also work more cautiously.
Focusing on building categories, not just portfolios, is what creates lasting change‚Äîespecially in a market as diverse and dynamic as India.¬†

How do you make a parrot talk differently when it has to earn its bonuses, Dilip. Even if someone makes toilet paper VCs will ask - what are you disrupting and what‚Äôs your IP and how can you scale 100X in two seasons. Delusion is a real thing in today‚Äôs world.
Ecosystem-first mindset over ego‚ÄîIndia needs category creators, not gatekeepers.

Love how you focus on growing the whole category, not just chasing winners. That kind of long-term thinking is rare and so needed in India right now. Real change happens when the ecosystem rises together.

Dilip Kumar, true impact isn‚Äôt about owning every deal‚Äîit‚Äôs about growing the whole category. Like how a rising tide lifts all boats, supporting competitors can expand the market and create new opportunities for everyone. India‚Äôs startup ecosystem needs that mindset shift‚Äîmore builders, more breakthroughs, less gatekeeping.

VCs should ask themselves:

I've seen in Indian VC market, most folks look for industry experience, like how many years the founder has been in the industry, what he di,d and more, but as we've seen, most successful company founders have different perspective to see the new indsty and they hold the power of distption. In the Valley, they promote bold ideas and founders. Hopefully, Indian VCs will also create a newer version or model to support young founders with a not-so-industry-led thesis.

Dilip, philosophically what you say makes sense. Practically, not as much. I'll tell you why. 

If I am building something truly disruptive (which I am... you know about Mindei), 1) I know it's going to be a big burner right up front, and 2) the risks, incl. but not limited to financial risks are significantly high. 

On top of this, my limited experience tells me Indian VC ecosystem is still not ready to invest in true disruptive, early-stage startups from first-time founders. America is yet to fully export the culture of taking risky bets with patient capital to India. 

As founder therefore, I am playing a high-stakes game with the pool of possibly interested VCs being really small. 

And then if I make them go through the kind of grind you mention ... I might reduce the pool even further. 

It's a buyers' market (the buyer being the VC). 

So whilst I try to get the investor-founder fitment right (which is why we've been talking :)) -- I don't try to make a big deal about it. Because one has to consider all aspects, and the sustainability of the venture above all, in making key decisions such as this. 

On a separate note, is there an application form for being invited to the podcast? :)

Well said Dilip. Can we talk? 
Hint: blue ocean opportunity + Indian market + Healthcare segment

While fundraising often centers around the financial ask, founders should also consider the non-monetary value a VC can bring to the table. May be they can seek below as well apart from financial ask
	‚Ä¢	Access to networks that open doors to customers, talent, and partners.
	‚Ä¢	Expertise in marketing, branding, and tech to strengthen your core.
	‚Ä¢	Founder communities, even for those not funded, to learn from peers across sectors.

Let's all dream & imagine as thats what is the base root of change. Us, the black sheep.... The outcasts are the ones that bring the change.

Love this post Dilip; couldn‚Äôt agree more. The game has changed, and it‚Äôs refreshing to see a mindset that‚Äôs focused on building for today‚Äôs time, not clinging to playbooks from the past. Building strong ecosystems and growing categories is what really matters now.
Dilip Kumar how to be part of the podcast

I believe encouraging open dialogues between founders and VCs can lead to more innovative solutions. It's refreshing to see Rainmatter's commitment to elevating the whole industry, not just individual players. Let's keep pushing for that change together.

VCs shaping the ecosystem beyond just their portfolio is exactly what India‚Äôs startup scene needs. Supporting category growth over individual status creates a ripple effect that benefits all players.
Love this mindset, your ecosystem-first thinking is what truly drives a  long-term change. More power to funds like yours that prioritise categories over competition üëè

Much of this also applies outside the venture world.
In SMBs, too many deals are decided by signaling: who sold, who bought, who else is in.

text:
Everyone wants to live longer, but no one wants to do the boring stuff that actually makes it happen- eat right, move and sleep well. 

Longevity isn‚Äôt about living forever. It‚Äôs about staying healthy and capable for as long as possible.
comments: Valid point
sometimes it even takes a lifetime commitment to become a farmer ;)
Consistency plays a crucial role too. It sounds boring until you realise it quietly builds everything you're chasing.
There is so much noise around us telling one product is going to solve everything without putting much effort...we don't want boring....we lose interest when we don't see immediate results

Ozzie Strbac create more capacity OR more resilience OR better boundaries? The challenge we face as we become enlightened is we feel more deeply so we have less tolerance. It‚Äôs quite painful. What do you suggest?
Do the boring stuff. Sleep. Dilip Kumar let‚Äôs share our top sleep tips üò¥
Eating well should not be boring, it should be invigorating and produce a sense of calm. Even better if meals are shared.

Truth! Everyone‚Äôs chasing longevity like it‚Äôs a tech upgrade, but skip the basics and it‚Äôs just a longer buffering screen. 

Sleep, movement, food‚Ä¶ and don‚Äôt forget sanity. What‚Äôs the point of a long life if your mind‚Äôs burnt out halfway?

Great point Dilip Kumar. Thanks for sharing. 

Most people still overlook the importance of holistic eating‚Äîchoosing convenience and price over clean, organic food. What we eat literally becomes us, yet toxic chemicals continue to find a way into our diets.

Today, less than 1% of urban India consumes organic food.

That‚Äôs where Organik Truck steps in‚Äîmaking wholesome, organic food more affordable and accessible in Mumbai. Finally, clean eating is no longer out of reach.
Most realise only after a hit or a long medical bill, sadly.
Just consistency on the basic boring stuff is the hack üíØ

The real pursuit is not living longer, it is living better for longer. Most people underestimate how much the ordinary disciplines: food, movement, and sleep shape an extraordinary life over decades. It is not glamorous, but it is what endures.
Discipline builds longevity ‚Äî but the real win is making it fun. Cross that barrier, enjoy the process, and tweak it to fit you. That‚Äôs how you stay in the game.
maybe a longevity pill is not so far off :D
People don't realise how painful a long life with poor health can be. Medicines can bring you longevity but not good health.
The life is in the boring and slow moments only

Anyone wishing to live forever is just being delusional

We all should aim for longevity that shouldn't turn us into burdens for ourselves, family and others.

I felt quite surprised when a woman once wished for death for her dear husband. The man has been battling a terminal illness that drained the family's finances and demanded so much care. It was very evident the family was stressed so thin
The secret to a long and happy tail-wagging life? Good habits make all the difference üêæ.
Longevity I think is about renewal more than living longer
Most good things we can do for our health are free. Exercise, good quality sleep, sunlight, moving around!

People chase life hacks and magic pills, but the real secret is consistency in the basics.

The ‚Äúboring stuff‚Äù mentioned above has been known forever‚Ä¶no amount of health-tech solutions, biohacks and supplements, which is what everyone seems to be ‚Äúinvesting‚Äù in, will ever change that fundamental truth. 

The fact is that if mindsets were changed, there would be no need for a lot of those money-making solutions‚Ä¶kind of like if folks lived healthy lives, the medical industry would suffer üòÄ

‚ÄúWhy do you think I'm the best player in the world? Because I never get bored with the basics. I never get bored with the basics.‚Äù

Just because something is basic doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs easy.

It‚Äôs always Nutrion , movement and Sleep which takes priority over everything that‚Äôs fancy in the market

Celebrating a big monetary win in the stock market with alcohol, leads to more chances of you not being able to enjoy the benefits of those wins üòä
