I have noticed a pattern - that these topics usually get mired in debates around what works and what doesn‚Äôt work, what is good, what is bad, etc.

There are enough people who will vouch for intermittent fasting - whereas there will be others who will vouch for not fasting, and eating small meals multiple times a day.

There are people who will say don‚Äôt eat X, and others who will say, eat only X! And no matter what X is, you will find someone to fight for it!

And there are some, like Warren Buffet who eat burgers and drink Coke - and are fully fit at 90!

For such an important topic, something that impacts everyone, the level of confusion you see, is simply mind boggling!

Invariably, the point that gets lost in all the noise - is that it‚Äôs not about which specific model you adopt. It‚Äôs about the fact that you adopt it fully - not just pick and choose what suits you, what is convenient!

I am sure there will be someone in the planet who will endorse eating ice cream all day, and running a marathon to burn it all off, and swears that it works for them! Don‚Äôt just pick the ice cream, if you aren‚Äôt going to also run the marathon!!

One should aim for an outstanding quality of life as long as one is alive. That takes effort and consistency.  That can be boring. And who wants to keep making the effort. But anyone who sees the light at the end of the tunnel will persevere. I can count on the fingers of one hand the times I have missed my daily workout with my trainer. Even with a torn knee muscle I would sit and work out. Consistency builds motivation. Not the other way round.
Healthspan >>>>> Lifespan
Success in anything comes from doing the simple, often boring things consistently. This holds true for longevity as well.

Health is most misused and misunderstood word of our generation.

* All founders want to build a big company, but very few people actually want to do the mundane stuff to building things one block at a time.

I practise

Living forever is not really an aim for many, it's the ability to remain independent even in your elderly years, which is the dream, not just financially but physically as well. But many people aim towards achieving financial freedom while neglecting their physical aspect.

The ‚Äútruth bomb:‚Äù  People want to live longer, but then skip sleep, binge junk, and treat movement like a chore. Longevity compounds of small, boring habits.
Longevity requires consistency‚Äîeat right, move, and sleep well to stay healthy and capable longer! Dilip Kumar

Living Fuller >> Living Longer

Dear Dilip, no one wants to die early, thus, as per their understanding and efforts are doing all right things as advised.

Btw,

Hindustan mein sabke paas healthy hone ke liye time aur paise nahi hai par bimaar hone ke liye sab kuch hai.

Instead of our lifespan.

text:
Big fan of what Y Combinator has done for founders. But I‚Äôve never understood the obsession with building a YC equivalent in India by investors here. I‚Äôm convinced it will never happen. Not because we lack talent or ambition, but because YC wasn‚Äôt just a structure. It was the outcome of a rare mix of time, place, and cultural defaults.

YC emerged in a place where risk was cheap, talent was abundant, trust was a default & failure was celebrated as a credential. India has almost none of those ingredients in the same proportion yet.

Indian founders are world class at surviving, hacking & stretching resources. But YC worked because it taught founders to focus on scaling instead of surviving.
Indian early stage capital still acts like it's lending money , not taking risk. Even seed rounds come with board seats and monthly reporting. 

The genius of YC was its narrative monopoly. They created status & not just capital. India‚Äôs status economy works differently. You can‚Äôt manufacture prestige in India without a IIT, IIM next to your name.

India won‚Äôt have its YC. But maybe that‚Äôs a good thing. 
What we need in India is founder first micro VCs with real skin in the game. A media and narrative engine that spotlights Indian builders solving Indian and world problems from India.
comments: Love this take Dilip!

In one of the interviews  Mr Sabeer Bhatia (hotmail founder) said that most VCs in India are people operating with a PE mindset in the name of VCs. 
Apart from the incubators and accelerators, the funding ecosystem available ahead also decides the confidence and structure of early stage company's DNA. 
Well put Dilip Kumar  the interlink between both the ecosystems in India currently.

True 
Startups need more than just Capital... Ecosystem, Experience, (Investor's skin in the game)...
We can't compete we YC but need a Indian version of it

India needs its own model, absolutely.

We may not be well served by models that de-emphasize hiring, or emphasize growth at any cost.

What we need are models that result in sustainable employment generation, sustainable growth.

The reason the IT services industry has worked so well, is because of this. But obviously there are issues with that model - it was perfect for a previous generation. We have to build a better model for today - higher up the value chain, delivering better results per employee.
Insightful, thank you Dilip

This really resonates. I was recently discussing with my co-founder (based in the US) how differently things function at a systems level ‚Äî the way structure, risk, and innovation are approached is fundamentally different from what we see here.

In our conversations with VCs here, we‚Äôve observed that there can be some hesitation around newer, less familiar technologies. This cautious approach, while understandable, can sometimes become a bottleneck for early-stage startups working on disruptive or deep-tech ideas that need early belief to grow.

It would be great to see more founder-first micro VCs who truly resonate with the risk-return-impact mindset.

Really inspiring to see you holding this vision, Dilip. That kind of aligned mindset is what fuels real innovation - not "destructive" interference, but "resonating" belief.
In my experience working with Indian founders, I‚Äôve seen an incredible bias for hustle and survival. But we need an ecosystem that encourages velocity, not just frugality.
Great stuff !! I agree..
Thought provoking and hit the Bulls eyes.
Problem statement is clear. Let's see anyone can do something on this.

I agree with everything you said, but I think we need to look beyond just the lack of a strong narrative. Saying India's main problem is storytelling or marketing feels like we're missing the real issue ‚Äî which is focus.

A lot of the well-known ‚Äúdropout founders‚Äù from Harvard or Stanford got into those colleges just to drop out and use the brand name to raise money. Their businesses often aim for quick profits by serving mass markets ‚Äî not real innovation. In India, we‚Äôve copied the outer layer of that model ‚Äî the hype, fast growth, and name-dropping ‚Äî but without the systems or culture to support it.

Many of India‚Äôs biggest startups aren't led by founders trying to solve real problems. They're more focused on PR and attention than on building long-term solutions. That‚Äôs why we got 10-minute grocery delivery before we fixed Bengaluru‚Äôs traffic, Delhi‚Äôs air pollution, or the lack of affordable housing in crowded cities.

Maybe we don‚Äôt need a YC-style program in India. Maybe what we need is something slower, more thoughtful, and truly built for the challenges we face here.
Great perspective

Could not agree more! No need to build in India just because it exists in the West. Let us first build trust, integrity and governance and another venture that will exist for a few months or years and leave investors and consumers in the dust.

Sorry for Hijacking the comment for something that I am conceptualising along the lines. I am prototyping a framework for early stage build which includes founder personality and interests along build methodology, toolkits and case studies. If anyone else is working on the same, let's connect?

One thing to add is that India is a fast-growing economy, but also one that‚Äôs had the benefit (and burden) of watching mature markets evolve before us. In many ways, we‚Äôre standing on the shoulders of ecosystems that took the bold risks, so we don‚Äôt always need to reinvent the wheel or absorb the same hits.

And while it‚Äôs true that we might never have a YC-style moment, it doesn‚Äôt mean we can‚Äôt create something uniquely Indian. The few risk-takers we do have might be small in number, but they‚Äôll define the narrative shift with the right kind of capital and storytelling.

Totally agree that YC was a product of a unique cocktail‚Äîtime, place, culture‚Äîand blindly replicating it here may miss the point. But maybe the problem is exactly that: we keep trying to copy-paste playbooks from other economies without adapting them to our context. India needs its own blueprint.

That said, I still admire those taking inspiration from YC to build founder-first ecosystems here. The intent matters. Because the gap between the rising number of aspiring entrepreneurs and the kind of real, thoughtful support available is still very real. We need systems that understand Indian founders‚Äînot just fund them.

Dilip Kumar, as someone who's been a huge fan of YC, binge-watching demo days, studying their essays, quoting Paul Graham like gospel I‚Äôve always felt this quiet discomfort whenever people said, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs just recreate YC here.‚Äù
It always felt... incomplete. Like copying the shape of something without understanding the soil it grew from.
Silicon Valley in the mid-2000s was a wild experiment of cheap failure and expensive dreams.
India, for better or worse, was (and still is) a country where failure costs real social capital, not just dollars.
Highly Insightful
So well articulated
India will do very well by following the bootstrap first raise money later strategy. That‚Äôs the 1Mby1M mantra.
Give me a few mil and two years and i'll prove you wrong.
India VC fund only those ideas that have been copied from west if you create something specific to indian population need ... they never consider that

I think both media & VCs will also need to build conviction on how we can build global consumer companies out of India. While we continue to invest & shine the spotlight on great global SaaS companies coming out of India, we will need greater risk appetite to build truly global consumer companies out of India.

Nonetheless, we‚Äôre trying to build the best platform to introduce screens & internet to young kids around the world at Kidzovo.

Will build this soon enough Dilip Kumar... thanks for the nudge. Having been through enough of these flaky IC meetings, where exactly the same mentality of loaning money exists... I've decided to build and help others build...very soon, hopefully. But thanks for keeping the fire burning and reminding us all that the need is urgent and real...

YC thrived in a culture that celebrated failure and rewarded the ambition to scale. In India, we need to build an ecosystem that acknowledges the value of risk and lets founders fail without feeling like they‚Äôve lost everything. Maybe that‚Äôs the true barrier to creating a YC-like model here.

india doesn‚Äôt need a YC clone.
it needs a system that rewards velocity, not vanity.
and backers who bet like founders ‚Äî not gatekeepers with term sheets.
i will say many things can be learned from their model... entirely separate question will or will not model will work..
This really made me pause. Maybe India‚Äôs strength is that we‚Äôre not following the usual path and that‚Äôs where the real magic begins.
Cultural DNA different hai , sir ji...you can't make apples wear banana skins üòä

Someone who gave me my 1st lessons in modern age startup gyan told me that in India VC is not venture capitalist but is vulture capitalist. Had our 1st hand experience with few which made us walk the tight rope without the funding support. 
AND we are happy. 

India is still a long way to get maturity in startup/ entrepreneurship space

YC worked because it was built on a unique set of cultural and economic conditions, and trying to replicate that here might miss the point. The real opportunity for India is in fostering homegrown, founder-first VCs who can truly support risk-taking and scaling. Looking forward to seeing how the Indian ecosystem evolves in its own way!

I think it's apple and oranges comparison, SV is a mature environment with  successful entrepreneurs who have either joined VC firms or have started one. Also ease of business, unlike India, govt is non existent. The undergraduate and masters programs encourage innovation, therefore the comparison will reflect a stark difference. I had in one of my comments in similar context posted about how ebays website was non functional during the first Presentation but still got funded by the same VC. When i asked this question to well know VC in India, they said honestly in India this will never be acceptable. The mindset is not yet there, i guess, but hopefully sooner than later we will get there.
India‚Äôs ecosystem is unique its challenges demand homegrown solutions, not carbon copies of Silicon Valley models.

Americans have ingenuity in making money. Indians have ingenuity in saving money. Bit oversimplified. But it tells you a lot about the differences in our risk appetite, startup culture, and investment/consumption ethos, Dilip Kumar.
Interesting take Dilip Kumar Our challenges and expectations are different,  we should have our own system for sure

Dilip Kumar Do you think this will actually happen in India?
I believe this is a deep-rooted issue in the Indian mindset. I‚Äôve studied a lot of YC content on fundraising, but what they teach doesn‚Äôt work in early-stage investor meetings in India. Investors rarely challenge their beliefs. To change this mindset, we need more founder-led early-stage funds.

I agree with your insights on the lower cost of risk and capital, but I respectfully disagree that we can't have a YC-equivalent here. If you look at the data from some of YC's batches, more than 50% of the companies originate from outside the U.S.

          Take a look at the stats from the YC Summer 2021 batch:

                    377 companies across 47 countries, representing over 4 billion people worldwide.
                    About 50% of the companies were based outside the U.S.. Top countries, excluding the U.S., included:
                    India (33)
                    UK (18)
                    Mexico (17)
                    Canada (18)
                    Brazil (11)
                    Singapore (12)

         These numbers demonstrate the growing global appeal and the increasing talent coming from non-U.S. countries. With India's thriving startup ecosystem and an abundance of entrepreneurial talent, there‚Äôs definitely potential to create a YC-like model right here.

"Bharat Combinator" :) :) :) 

Ciju Baby, COO, https://www.pplio.com

Dilip Kumar I agree with your views. Unlike YC, the risk appetite of Investors here is not very high. As you mentioned, the investors at seed level also demand board seat and monthly reporting. I found the situation worse than this. The incubators and the Fund  Manager supported by the Govt fund are demanding Board Seats and higher dilution from ideation or pre-revenue stage startups. Dilip Kumar Thats exactly what we are doing at Upsparks Capital  we invest our money with our own conviction in pre-seed stage , invested in over 70 plus companies in last 5 years . Having built kaleyra previously we exactly know what a indian founder needs to build a startup from india üáÆüá≥

Dilip Kumar I agree with you! But when an entire society is obsessed about the tags of something (Ex-IIT/IIM/MAANG), copying a idea/mechanism that is successful elsewhere, we can‚Äôt expect better! 

Early stage VC‚Äôs/Seed funding partners are evaluating any business idea on the parameter of Founding team Tags, revenue or product ready to market! No one are in a state of mind to groom or guide the new and innovative ideas. So there won‚Äôt be any YC or equivalent in India until someone who comes from humbled bg of no tags building successful ventures, moving to VC/AF and creating that specific ecosystem.

India needs an ecosystem that guides, supports or invest in new ideas that are necessary for our real time problems! Not some fancy names or tags or some first copy versions of other country innovations

True, pedigree and capital signal potential.
But trust is built through narratives that scale.

Because you can‚Äôt fundraise belief.

Absolutely spot on, Dilip. YC wasn‚Äôt just capital it was cultural alchemy. India doesn‚Äôt need to mimic Silicon Valley; it needs to craft its own playbook. We need VCs who bet on grit over pedigree, skin in the game over spreadsheets. It‚Äôs time we build ecosystems that don‚Äôt just fund dreams but believe in them before they‚Äôre proven.

From what I understand, this is the case because a lot of VC funds raise money from LPs that are not Indian and see these investments akin to the ones that are made in the public markets, backing the possibility of plain pecuniary return over taking the risk of funding something disruptive. Even the completely indian funds in terms of teams and LPs tend not to fund ideas till it has already generated some amount of traction - this significantly cuts down on the risk capital available for innovation that can disrupt the reality as we see today (say, for example flying taxis - a place where there is active investment in India). Even when such capital is available, it is available at tiny ticket sizes (INR 1- 2cr), which puts pressure on the innovator to continuously return to markets to raise money and move to market with either a product that's not too different from run of the mill products available to as the pressure to derisk more and more with for every new investment mounts.
The closest thing that I have seen to the Y-Combinator ecosystem in India are the IITM Incubation Cell and INCeNSE (IISc incubation cell), which work on innovative ideas that can make an impact.
Very well put, Dilip.

The conversation needs to shift from India-specific to world-specific. 
With AI, more and more global problems are itching to be solved, and more and more Global startups will emerge.  From the USA, Israel, India, Africa...who knows?
We need to be global in our perspective and GLOBAL in our outcomes. Maybe China's already getting there before us. Let's catch up FAST ........
Sharp take. India needs its own playbook, not a YC replica.Dilip Kumar
Such a sharp take. YC wasn‚Äôt just a model, it was a moment. India needs its own story, not a copy. Love the call for founder-first support that truly fits our context.

Brilliantly framed, Dilip Kumar . YC wasn‚Äôt built‚Äîit was emergent, born from a trust-first, failure-tolerant culture. India‚Äôs still in a ‚Äòvalidation economy‚Äô‚Äîwhere degrees precede daring, and compliance precedes conviction. But our edge isn‚Äôt mimicry, it‚Äôs reinvention. We won‚Äôt have a YC because we don‚Äôt need one. What we‚Äôll have is a founder-first, India-native capital stack‚Äîscrappy, skin-in-the-game, and grounded in solving for 1.4B. Prestige will follow outcomes, not pedigrees.
Looks like a challenge to all.

I agree that while we have incredible talent, the surrounding support structures differ significantly. The focus on survival rather than scaling is indeed a critical challenge for many founders here. Rather than trying to replicate YC, perhaps we should champion the creation of a tailored ecosystem that prioritizes risk-taking and celebrates local success stories.

The funding ecosystem isn't just about copying structures Dilip, it's about understanding the unique DNA of a startup ecosystem. Our founders are resilient problem-solvers who need capital that truly gets their hustle.
Dilip Kumar : how would define a micro vc in the indian context .. eg size of funds / investments being what? Also sector focused?

Based on my limited understanding, YC is great at coaching founders and inculcating a high tolerance for failure. In India, the quality of entrepreneurship coaching and mentorship is limited to founders who have had scarcity/survival mindset hence you get an ecosystem limited to those type of founders. Also as the MD of one of India's largest companies once mentioned to me, Indians are fundamentally low integrity (dishonest)--which makes it difficult to have a YC like system in the first place. If you are fighting for survival and fear failure, it is not surprising that you are also dishonest--we will be incentivised to be high integrity if we live in a society that doesn't discrimnate against failure/mistakes. 

At a base level, we lie because we are scared.
Very insightful, thank you Dilip

Second what Varun Aggarwala says in the comments. Our lack of vision and cohesiveness with executions backed by risk capital is our biggest Achilles heel. Long way to go till we have our own Gingko. We can keep on manufacturing cheap knock-offs of Whoop or some such service based products that bring us value, but tech that changes our way of life of impacts humankind will not originate in India. And that, I think is ok. The purpose of a business is to make money, as long as we make money from cheap knockoffs we should be happy about keeping our LPs on the same page. The sooner we accept this the better it is for us.
KPH exists for the same reason!

Loved this. So many points that really made me pause and reflect. India‚Äôs path will look different, and maybe that‚Äôs where the magic lies. Rooting for whatever version of founder first emerges here.

I was discussing the same with someone this morning, the difference in looking at it from a 'Portfolio' perspective, vis-a-vis a 'Standalone' manner. YC does that, it allows companies in it's portfolio to fail, and it doesn't micro-manage - not every company can be a winner.

Dear Dilip Kumar: Y combinator focused on disruptive talent and deep-tech. Unfortunately most Indian VCs can't think beyond fraud snake oil peddling non scientific ventures (huge problem with talent in India too).

Ginkgo Bioworks needs a Y combinator and not Rainmatter. It is about concentrated talent and DISRUPTIVE tech first mindset.

If and when things become serious in India, we will see a Y combinator equivalent.

text:
Because we invest in healthcare, I get this question all the time: Will AI replace doctors? As a technology optimist I don‚Äôt claim to have all the answers. But i feel this question usually reveals how little we understand both about AI & healthcare.

When people say AI will replace doctors and teachers in the next decade. They  assume that intelligence is enough to make an impact and forgets that trust is the real currency in both healthcare and education.

Doctors don‚Äôt just prescribe, they hold your hand during a cancer diagnosis. Teachers don‚Äôt just deliver content but they spot the kid falling behind, build confidence, and unlock potential. AI can assist, but it can‚Äôt replace human empathy and trust.

So is AI important? Absolutely.
AI can read scans better than most radiologists. It can solve for homework & personalise lessons faster than a teacher. It can democratize access to world class knowledge, in any language, at near zero cost.

But can it replace the human relationship that sits at the core of these professions? AI doesn‚Äôt replace doctors. It replaces inefficiencies around them. Likewise AI won‚Äôt replace teachers. But it can free them from admin so they can actually teach

Tech is best when it‚Äôs invisible. When it supports human work & not erase it.
Yes, AI will change healthcare & education. The goal of AI shouldn't be to replace doctors & teachers. It‚Äôs to make a billion people feel like they finally have one. That‚Äôs the real opportunity & that‚Äôs where the best builders will focus i feel.
comments:
Dilip Kumar is this true in the area of loneliness too? With so many AI chatbots getting developed to help people beat loneliness. 
I often question myself - Isn't that human touch, someone to hear me out makes the entire difference here ?
Very true. Jhaadu Ki Jhappi will always be relevant, be it doctors or teachers.

We couldn't agree more. At Telma AI, we build AI assistants to support people, not replace them. In healthcare, the human connection is irreplaceable. But what AI can do is take the busywork off people‚Äôs plates, giving them more space to prescribe and hold hands during a cancer diagnosis.

This is such a thoughtful perspective. I completely agree that AI's role should be to enhance and support human efforts, not replace the empathy and trust that define professions like healthcare and education. The idea of AI addressing inefficiencies while allowing professionals to focus on what truly matters‚Äîhuman connection‚Äîis inspiring. Thank you for sharing this!

Perfectly said. The real disruption in healthcare won't come from AI replacing doctors ‚Äî it'll come from AI making it feel like every patient has a doctor who listens, remembers, and acts with insight. It's not about intelligence; it's about presence. And presence, especially in care, is built on trust ‚Äî not just accuracy.
Totally agree ..  üßë‚Äç‚öïÔ∏è  + ü§ñ >>  üßë‚Äç‚öïÔ∏è

AI can significantly enhance diagnostic accuracy, speed, and efficiency by analyzing complex data, identifying subtle anomalies in imaging, and even suggesting personalized treatment plans. This can reduce the workload of healthcare professionals, especially by automating routine or redundant tasks and streamlining processes.

However, the adoption of AI depends heavily on doctors‚Äô willingness to embrace new technology. Studies show that some physicians resist AI recommendations, especially when they conflict with their own judgment, often due to training gaps or concerns about professional credibility. This resistance can stem from traditional roles, perceived threats to expertise, or discomfort when patients arrive well-informed or with their own research.

Ultimately, for AI to reach its full potential in healthcare, there needs to be a cultural shift: doctors must be open to collaboration with AI, view it as a tool to augment rather than replace their expertise, and receive proper training to integrate AI insights into clinical decision-making. This partnership can lead to better patient outcomes and more human-centered care, provided both technology and mindsets evolve together.

AI will certainly replace the kind of professionals ( including some kinds of doctors, lawyers, architects and many others ) who work at the back end -  with little human interaction. 

The current inflexion point in human history due to AI seems to be very different from earlier shifts - at no point of time during the earlier revolutions did the Agency pass from human hands. Now - it is a matter of time before it does. 

The development of AGI (only a matter of time) means we are possibly creating a species superior to Home Sapiens. And the second and third order effects of that will be dangerously unpredictable.

The more I‚Äôm seeing/using AI, the more I‚Äôm liking it. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs replacing anyone, as far as you know how to use it well. We have to use it exactly how we started using the computers, to be more efficient and productive. That‚Äôs it. 

Not to give up your creativity and originality and definitely not to give up your core (whatever that core is).
The empathy, along with the judgment required in teaching and treating, cannot be delivered by AI. However, in both professions, AI can support to excel.

Thank you for sharing such a thoughtful perspective on the role of AI in healthcare and education. Your insights highlight the critical importance of human empathy and trust in these fields, which AI, despite its impressive capabilities, cannot replicate.

AI is not just going to change the diagnosis landscape in the next couple of years, it will eventually even replace surgeons with finer and more precise abilities. That‚Äôs a space where the ultimate result matters way more than any other metrics.
With teachers I do believe there is an element of that extra, the extra push, that element of support and encouragement that‚Äôs very humane and may, may not be replaced fully. Though with AI taking over the knowledge imparting element very easily, the paradigm itself won‚Äôt have enough reference points to support having enough teachers with that / for that extraordinary element. It‚Äôs an interesting phase.

AI can stretch the general levels of expertise available across the board and make it consistent and repeatable. In expert hands, it can push boundaries, and then make that the new normal. It's this multiplier effect that is exciting and game changing. 

Quoting from personal experience, I got a scan done and the radiologist at the diagnostic lab graded a module as TIRADS-4. But when the FNAC doesn't reveal anything and I got the scan done again by an experienced doctor this time, it was reclassified as TIRADS-3. A shadow seen earlier was wrongly thought to be solid cyst particles and the experienced doctor could call out the difference. If this expertise is fed into the reinforced learning loop of An AI system, it could have interpreted the scan correctly, the first time, saving all the trouble, anxiety and money.

Brilliantly articulated Dilip Kumar.This perspective cuts through the noise around AI fear mongering. Trust, empathy, and human connection are irreplaceable especially in fields like healthcare and education where the stakes are deeply personal. AI should be seen as an enabler, not a replacement. The real innovation will lie in how we design systems that amplify human capability rather than attempt to mimic it.

ai won‚Äôt replace doctors, but it might change who (or what) patients are willing to trust in different moments.

for some, it‚Äôs still the human touch.
for others, it‚Äôs the privacy and immediacy of a well-designed system.

trust doesn‚Äôt always have to come from a person‚Äîsometimes it‚Äôs the design itself that makes people feel safe.

AI is revolutionizing healthcare by enhancing diagnosis, training, and efficiency, but it cannot replace the trust, empathy, and human connection at the heart of the doctor-patient relationship‚Äîits real value lies in supporting and empowering clinicians, not replacing them

Very well put. And I truly feel that while AI is great with many things, it is just not human, and this "small difference" makes a world of an impact!

My father was a teacher, and I hear from his students even today telling me about how he made them feel. Not what he taught, but the relationship he created with them, motivating, helping, sometimes even scolding. It is that entirety of his humanness that they remember. Not the lessons he taught!

The Future is not ‚ÄòAI‚Äô alone!
It‚Äôs ‚ÄòHUMAN + AI‚Äô !
AI will not Replace, it will Enhance Human!
AI is needed to make tasks easier but it's not going to replicate human connection which is a core part of these jobs

The worry is it can go the customer care way. While the back offices and customer care support teams have been a good addition overall, but it has put a layer between customer and team and we all have been there when we just want to pick up the phone and talk to someone. It doesn‚Äôt matter if AI is invisible or visible, what may matter more is it is putting more distance between doctor and patients or not
So beautifully written.

Can't agree more. Been at the intersection of both, Tech AI and the edtech/healthcare sectors, I've lived that fear of being redundant at some point. But the truth is, it's an enabler, not a replacement. The ability to understand the emotion, make the human being in front feel seen when backed with AI enhances and brings velocity to what we are solving for. The same goal to make them win.
Unless we intend to make humans also think, behave and act like robots, AI will not be able to replace humans in many fields esp healthcare
https://youtu.be/zyrvFuqfHWc?si=vjPzUGEbXxrKEJZ9

As a PM in healthtech, I see this play out every day. AI isn‚Äôt here to replace doctors, it‚Äôs here to amplify their impact. 
Whether it‚Äôs helping triage faster, generating clinical summaries, or nudging patients toward better adherence, the best use of AI is when it fades into the background and empowers the human connection, not replaces it.

A long time back when tele-health was at the top of the hype cycle, I told a high flying exec the same thing.. Healthcare and Education are high touch engagements.. You can use AI for many things including the diagnostics but AI cannot replace the human in the loop.. Case in point - We are building a product for therapy support but finer nuances of what's required in an Indian context is not something that the LLM could give you.. AI is limited to documented, training data and case studies on pub med, not the undocumented experience of meeting over 20-30 patients everyday with knowledge of local demographics, environment, climate, diet, endemic diseases etc. For that you need the human.

Great post. As a doctor, my two bits is that accuracy alone isn‚Äôt enough, AI needs contextual judgment. If the training data reflects systemic gaps (like missed diagnoses in women or underrepresented populations), we risk scaling those inequities.
Trust comes not just from empathy, but from transparency and accountability. The question isn‚Äôt just can AI outperform us? but can it understand why we choose what we do?
That said, I also believe AI can be a powerful force for good, especially in resource-constrained settings. Supporting overburdened systems, aiding early screening in rural areas, or reducing admin load. These are places where AI can genuinely improve access and outcomes.
The key is designing it to amplify the human, not replace it.

Really appreciate this post Dilip Kumar, in fact ties in with my thoughts in the next post in my series on how 'AI WILL replace doctors' (caveats given there!). Trust, relationship building and empathy is actually largely missing in the chaos of the healthcare system today, and thats likely where AI will replace certain doctors. And the doctors left will have more time, space and emotional bandwidth to build trust, empathy and relationships with their patients. Because the point as you've mentioned isn't whether AI will or will not replace doctors, its how do we fix our broken healthcare system and improve health outcomes for all. Sumukh Mysore - our long standing conversation on this and my posts seems to be on everyones mind!

Trust and empathy are all fine. But the REAL reason why AI will not replace a doctor is because you need HUMAN JUDGMENT for AI recommendations. And you need an expert (doctor) to exercise that judgment.

Teachers are a different issue altogether. For children, especially young children, human interaction and guidance are required for various reasons. A robotic solution will soon work for this, but society will insist on human connections for very young minds. For older children and adults, there is no reason for human teachers to continue to exist, once robotic systems improve some more.
Very rarely (almost never) have I felt any "human relationship" while visiting a doctor.

Tech is Best with its invisible, Beautiful line.
In any business, the tech is just a facilitator, not the core.

The fate of an EdTech does not depend on the UI quality or the speed at which it can dish out content or evaluate sheets. It's the back-end data, the content, the live or virtual tutor who has drafted and crafted the content and how optimised it is kept.

The success of a fintech does not lie in how fast it allows you to make and break ur investments. It's the financial advice that it can provide. The back-end team can raise the red flags, help you distinguish the benefits of bonds and mutual funds, and so on.

Similarly, AI is another tech, it's just an enabler, facilitator, accelerator in many cases, it's not meant to and WILL NOT be replacing core functions like doctors and educators.

Dilip, totally agree with your points. We should understand that AI or any path breaking tools is most critical to enhance the efficiency, precision and performance.  However the "real" decision will be routed by professionals driven by vast experience, Knowledge, reasoning and empathy. Though technology can identify and help connect data points, human intuition and wisdom alone can identify which of the critical data points to consider to make informed appropriate decisions.

AI won‚Äôt replace doctors, but it will take care of most primary consultations and assist in clinical decision-making. AI agents can listen first, summarize fast, and support doctors with timely insights. The future of healthcare is human-led and AI-assisted.

Being the first handler of AI-enabled products on ground, I see skepticism in the short term. But in the long run, AI won‚Äôt replace doctors, I feel it will become the silent backbone of healthcare enhancing decisions, reducing burnout and making quality care accessible at scale, without replacing the human touch.

Totally agree!

First, empathy can‚Äôt be replicated in machines. Both professions fuel on empathy. Besides, not only will AI change healthcare & education, it must. 

Ways in which AI can assist healthcare practitioners in disease screening, diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment is limitless. It‚Äôs an exciting time to witness the integration of ML and human health and disease.

AI replacing doctors? That's like saying a stethoscope will replace a doctor. Sure, it amplifies sound, but it doesn't diagnose heartbeats with empathy. 
Dilip, your perspective is spot on. AI is the sidekick, not the superhero. It handles the grunt work‚Äîlike triaging and data crunching‚Äîwhile humans bring the heart and soul to healthcare and education. 
In a world where trust is the real currency, AI can be the trusted assistant, but the human touch remains irreplaceable. Let's use AI to make a billion people feel like they finally have one.

Dilip Kumar very well said and resonates with the same thought I have, AI is here to stay and thrive but until it learns to have empathy and human emotions responses it will never be able to replace area‚Äôs where human touch is required. An interaction with doctor is not just transactional but most of the time half of patient‚Äôs problem goes away just by having interaction with doctor.
Tech is best when it‚Äôs invisible - simple yet profound

Yes it can in few situations. That's the reason inclusion of tech can get very critical here.

In few scenarios human becoming invisible also helps case to case basis. Toxicity and vengeance are often overlooked which AI may not bring to the table while interacting. 

For eg 

"ChatGPT fixed my 5-year jaw problem in a minute"- LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman shares viral Reddit win that doctors missed

https://m.economictimes.com/news/new-updates/chatgpt-fixed-my-5-year-jaw-problem-in-a-minute-linkedin-co-founder-reid-hoffman-shares-viral-reddit-win-that-doctors-missed/articleshow/120422455.cms

This is absolutely true! We, as health tech founders are majorly focusing towards improving inefficiencies using AI. Can't wait to see what the future of healthcare in India looks like and we're glad to be a part of it.

At the end of the day, AI isnt about displacing trust driven professions like healthcare and education.. The winners in this space won't be those who automate tasks for humans, but those who empower humans through technology.

I guess over 50% of today's patient-doctor interactions are not as critical as cancer. They don't require hand-holding or empathy as much as they require efficiency in speed and cost. And if AI ends up reducing case load by even 10-20% there will be a substantial displacement happening.
It will replace it for the people who are thinking things from practical aspect...
Wonderfully articulated!
Tech is built by human so assuming tech will surpass humans is still just a misconception.

The perspective on AI's healthcare impact lacks specificity. In a nation with a severe scarcity of doctors, and where access to highly skilled physicians is even more limited, AI offers a significant solution. It can begin by addressing the shortage through improved triaging and may eventually automate much of primary healthcare.

‚ÄúAI doesn‚Äôt replace doctors, it replaces inefficiencies around them‚Äù is potentially my favourite use case of AI. Help doctors do the administrative and scheduling tasks, especially related to insurance, and let them focus on providing empathy driven care to their patients.

In Indian context, the goal of making a billion people feel like they finally have access to Education & Healthcare is pretty much non-negotiable. I would extend this to the whole of 'Global South', which has been short on basic amenities. AI can and (ideally), should be used to augment & scale human capabilities to enable access to all. Because if the focus remains only on productivity & profitability, it is likely to lead to massive social disruptions.
Amazing thought process Dilip Kumar! Human relationship is the core of healthcare delivery, and the compassion that humans can show each other can surely not be replaced by AI.

Most of us already do a google search of our symptoms and perform self diagnosis and self prescription .. I think there will be use cases where AI will replace if the price is going to be near to zero

Absolutely nailed it!
Great to know that what goes beyond treatment is appreciated in today's chaotic healthcare scenario. The core of healthcare is the silent support a doctor gives as a gentle touch on hand to say I'm there for you, an empathetic ear to hear the challenges a patient faces as a person, leaving aside the medical concerns. The extra touch that goes in is sharing lives as human beings. What a teacher can do cannot be replaced..
The inspiration and the motivation 
AI can't sure see your capabilities which a mentor can envision or a doctor who can connect with their patient at all levels.
It's a bond of a lifetime!

AI can assist, but it can‚Äôt replace human empathy and trust. If it exists in teachers & Doctors, they're rare to find
Wrong Diagnosis, unwanted tests, investigations,surgeries to make few bucks, have become the norm 
Rather than instilling confidence, I have seen them shatter the child, teaching has become a side hustle to make some easy money than the upbringing of a child with healthy mind & body
I address victims of both these professions daily , the pain trauma instilled in them, makes me wonder ,once called Noble professions has become money making machine

The line - "tech is best when it's invisible" is super super super deep and insightful. Thanks for that! 

Plus, the insight about AI removing the friction is exactly what Mihir has been talking to me about for so long. He says that AI and human experts will co-exist and enable each other to serve others. 

Thanks for the post, Dilip!
Exactly - it's like people are accusing calculators will replace all mathematicians!

text:
Everyone today loves this grand narrative that "Tech will fix everything". Every week a news article or investor confidently declares that tech will fix healthcare & most entrepreneurs fall for this illusion of disruption. This narrative is doing more harm than good.

Most entrepreneurs today think, if we can build a beautifully designed app, use AI to chat, automate doctor-patient interactions, and scale it to millions of users, we can "solve" healthcare. 

It sounds great in a pitch deck. It almost never works in reality.

Why? Because healthcare isn't e-commerce. You can‚Äôt scale a hospital bed like a food delivery fleet. You can‚Äôt disrupt chronic disease with a better UI. You can‚Äôt solve trust with a chatbot. Healthcare isn‚Äôt a transaction, it‚Äôs a relationship.

If you're serious about fixing healthcare, start thinking from first principles.

Everyone wants to build the ‚ÄúUber of Healthcare.‚Äù But Uber works because a ride from point A to B is a simple transaction. Healthcare isn‚Äôt. You can‚Äôt just match a patient with a doctor and assume the job is done. Don't build a generic doctor consultation app with a new UI or a marketplace that lists thousand doctor names. Focus on depth of care, outcomes, and follow-up treatments before chasing millions of users. Build a connected system that only focuses on driving outcomes.

Don't over focus on AI without fixing the basics. AI can help a doctor diagnose faster. But it can‚Äôt replace the doctor. Yet, doctors alone won‚Äôt solve India‚Äôs healthcare crisis. They also need trained frontline workers assisted by smart tech. Build AI tools to assist doctors enable faster diagnoses. Don't oversell your AI engine or LLM models to a patient. 

It doesn‚Äôt matter if we have the best doctor or AI engine if the right medicine isn‚Äôt available. Up to 20% of medicines sold in India are fake or substandard. Counterfeit drugs are a massive problem & the Pharma companies are growing this $58 billion market. Perhaps a great usecase to use AI and tech to streamline the supply chain. 

So, can tech fix healthcare? Yes. 
But not by replacing doctors, hospitals, or traditional care systems. The biggest healthcare opportunities in India are not about disruption but augmentation.

Tech alone won‚Äôt fix Indian healthcare. But finding the right places to apply can make a 10x difference. Healthcare isn‚Äôt an industry that gets "disrupted" overnight. But it can be upgraded piece by piece, solving for what really matters. And if you understand that, you‚Äôll build something that actually works.
comments: Brilliantly articulated. Tech has a huge role to play, but only when it's grounded in the realities of how healthcare actually works. It‚Äôs not just about building sleek apps or throwing AI at the problem. They can support, not solve.
Humans have the insight so the AI would know and not have hallucinations.

Well Said...
Doctors do need a lot of support tech to bolster their practice..
Unfortunately the tug of war between the primacy of the tech platform "enrolling" doctors and a doctor deploying tech, has created a kind of a deadlock and not allowed tech to actually revolutionise healthcare delivery..

This is why we eVitalRx have been building for 4 years an infrastructure and now we launched PillO: Meds in Minutes to make medicines accessible when we need the most - aka qCommerce. Would love to speak to you about it.
A sharp, much-needed reality check‚Äîtech can enhance healthcare, but only when it respects its complexity, not oversimplifies it.

That's a good perspective on 'Tech will fix everything' narrative, especially in healthcare where distruption does not necessarily mean putting AI between a patient & the healthcare professional but rather AI around them so that the cluttered processes, wait times, etc can be reduced. I came across few MVPs & products recently which are designing LLM's for mental health space which a patient can access to & talk to before connecting to an actual professional.

Exactly. True innovation isn‚Äôt just about technology‚Äîit‚Äôs about understanding the real-world challenges and applying tech where it actually moves the needle. The best solutions don‚Äôt disrupt for the sake of it; they enhance what already works.
Tech can‚Äôt replace relationships, trust, or outcomes in healthcare. Augmentation, not disruption, is the real game-changer‚Äîpiece by piece, not overnight. Spot on! Dilip Kumar
True,it must be built brick by brick, with careful consideration of the risks involved.
Bharosa AI is doing exactly that - "the focus on depth of care and outcomes part", especially.
On point

Dilip Kumar

This is such a solid take! 

The whole "Uber of Healthcare" narrative oversimplifies a deeply complex system. 

Healthcare isn't just about transactions; it's about trust, continuity, and outcomes.

Tech can absolutely help, but not in the way most startups imagine‚Äîslapping AI on everything and calling it "disruption" isn‚Äôt the answer. 

Instead, the real impact comes from augmenting the system: improving diagnostics, streamlining supply chains, ensuring medicine authenticity, and empowering frontline workers.

It‚Äôs refreshing to see a take that focuses on first principles rather than just chasing scale. 

The biggest wins in healthcare won‚Äôt come from the flashiest tech but from solving real, foundational problems.

" The biggest healthcare opportunities in India are not about disruption but augmentation" - Excellent observation. Request you to write your views on the role of Govt in healthcare when you get some time....

Techie just a ‚Äútool‚Äù that can help in the process.

MINDSET change is the only way this can happen in a sustained way and for the long term.

And, it needs to be done with the youth in India.

Current emphasis is still on visual aesthetics vs real health‚Ä¶‚Äù‚Äùlooking‚Äù good being the primary emphasis.

Also, there‚Äôs a need to put more messaging out that shows the connection between physical exercise and mental health.
Tech can‚Äôt fix everything, but it can amplify what works. Focus on meaningful upgrades, not overnight disruption. Slow, steady, and impactful wins the race.
Well said! Focusing on augmentation rather than disruption is the key to meaningful progress in healthcare.

Healthcare management is a multifaceted field that requires a blend of strategic decision-making, human empathy, regulatory compliance, and real-time problem-solving. It involves coordinating medical professionals, managing resources, ensuring patient safety, and navigating complex healthcare policies‚Äîall while maintaining a patient-centered approach. While AI tools can enhance efficiency by analyzing data and automating administrative tasks, they lack the nuanced judgment, ethical reasoning, and interpersonal skills necessary for effective leadership. The ability to address unforeseen challenges, mediate conflicts, and make holistic decisions based on both data and human factors ensures that healthcare management remains an indispensable human-driven profession. 
Thank you for pointing that out sir! üëçüèΩüòä Dilip Kumar
Great advice!

Dilip, this was an absolute reality check disguised as a masterclass in common sense! Guess we‚Äôre all guilty of thinking ‚ÄúIf it works for pizza delivery, it must work for healthcare too.‚Äù It‚Äôs like trying to fix a broken leg with free Wi-Fi ‚Äì not exactly what the doctor ordered.
Tech isn‚Äôt the cure, but it can be the catalyst.

Love this note, Dilip!
We work in a different industry [concrete/ construction], but much of these principles/ learnings apply there as well!
THIS!

100%
This post will age well and I am sure within the next 2-3 years, there will be a lot of startups validating this post.

Finally, a take that doesn‚Äôt fall for the ‚ÄúAI will save the world‚Äù fantasy.

Too many startups believe better UI + AI chatbot = healthcare revolution. But healthcare isn‚Äôt a checkout cart‚Äîit‚Äôs a life-and-death relationship.

Biggest takeaway? Tech should augment, not replace.

- AI can assist doctors, but it won‚Äôt replace experience and trust.
- A sleek app won‚Äôt fix supply chain chaos or fake medicine issues.
- Scaling care isn‚Äôt about matching patients to doctors‚Äîit‚Äôs about ensuring follow-up, outcomes, and real impact.

If you‚Äôre serious about ‚Äúfixing‚Äù healthcare, stop chasing disruption hype and start solving real problems.

I get it. Every entrepreneur wants to build the ‚ÄòUber of Healthcare.‚Äô But unlike booking a ride, healthcare is personal, complex, and needs constant care. If you‚Äôre serious about making a difference, focus on augmenting existing systems with tech that enhances doctor-patient relationships and improves outcomes, not just on scaling for scale‚Äôs sake.

This is the first post I‚Äôve seen that actually gets healthcare right. 

The biggest wins in Indian healthcare will come from fixing logistics, follow-ups, and frontline support.

Not just throwing AI at the problem
Very informative & agree with insights
Finally someone called it out.
Dilip Kumar You hit the nail on the head, and I hope investors see it that way too.

What if we invert the problem? Instead of asking how tech can fix healthcare, ask how healthcare can evolve to leverage tech. Consider second-order effects: how can we redesign healthcare systems to naturally integrate AI, blockchain, and IoT, creating a symbiotic relationship that amplifies human expertise and trust?

Doctors are usually the most inefficient point in the journey from ailment to healing. 

Technology can definitely improve this inefficiency through multiple means. Removing the bottleneck, or offering alternate solutions should be a priority for anyone trying to solve for this.

I second your thoughts..
We don‚Äôt need to disrupt healthcare, but to transform it.
Make it accessible to everyone, make it efficient and portable (where one patient can move to another facility without carrying a big pile of records, just like EHR/FHIR in US) and most importantly help frontline workers in rapid diagnosis.
The truth is, we have the basic infrastructure required to accomplish all these things, but the people who can make it happen are not so willing to make it happen.
Example -
We already have Aadhar in place, equavelant to SSN in US, all we need to create a centralised system where every detail, every visit, every hospitalisation along with diagnoses and treatment gets updated in the real-time , making it easy to access by healthcare professionals at patient visit.
India has a very large talent pool and most of it is busy in job hunt whereas we are lagging behind in AI innovation, why not using it to become an AI powerhouse?
Which can transform healthcare, environment and whatnot!

Everyone wants to build the ‚ÄòUber of Healthcare,‚Äô but forget that in Uber, the worst-case scenario is a delayed ride. In healthcare, it‚Äôs a misdiagnosed disease. The stakes aren‚Äôt just higher‚Äîthey‚Äôre life and death.

Tech isn‚Äôt a magic pill; it‚Äôs a scalpel. Used right, it can make precision cuts to solve real bottlenecks; supply chains, diagnostics, access. Used wrong, it just adds another flashy app to an already broken system.

The real challenge? Not disruption, but integration. Not replacing doctors, but empowering them. Not chasing scale, but fixing what‚Äôs fundamentally broken. That‚Äôs where the real billion-dollar opportunities lie.

This post is a crash course on building healthcare product on Fundamental level. 

Really great insights Dilip Kumar
Tech is just an enabler, startups still need to solve real human problems to add value

I couldn‚Äôt agree more! Healthcare, especially when it comes to optimizing functional health, isn‚Äôt a one-size-fits-all problem. Even if we set aside the absolute need for empathy in wellness transactions, the simple fact that we are all bio-individuals means no two imbalances are identical.

ML &AI are not replacements for human expertise but critical tools in advancing research, enabling deeper insights from biodata. These technologies are essential for identifying patterns & forming the backbone of personalized interventions.
This is exactly where we are focused‚Äîdeveloping biodata-driven solutions that integrate 100% clean health supplementation and precision nutrition.
on point. tech is ONLY an enabler. it's what you aim to solve, how you solve and consistently so - that's what matters.
AI can suggest, but it can‚Äôt decide. The real focus should always remain in doctor-patient relationship.

Apart from just technology, with the corporatisation of healthcare services, driven by a profit motive- we really need to think about whether they have the right incentives at hand to focus on health.
If smart watch or phone could make people smarter then we wouldn't be dumb to believe that wearing a smart watch, or ring would make us healthy

Rightly said! The notion that tech alone can 'disrupt' healthcare oversimplifies the complexity of human well-being. Real impact comes from thoughtful integration ‚Äî using tech to empower doctors and frontline workers.

Dear Dilip, refer any statistics of metabolic illnesses, the prevalence is directly proportional with availability of medical resources and information. Rich vs poor, worker vs executive, rural vs urban etc., Health is multifactorial and related to natural lifestyle. Planning health itself is a deviation. Most wealthy individuals have poor healthspan and is due to additional stress associated with wealth. 
Biggest illness of humans unlike other organisms is greed to accumulate more than required, in all terms. 
AI shall be worsening health parameters at a faster pace than before due to associated stress inputs... 
The earlier major disruptions in humans that affected health majorly were
1. Discovery of fire
2. Invention of wheel

True... AI shouldn‚Äôt be everywhere, especially at the fundamental level.  AI can help reduce friction and make processes faster for both doctors and patients, but it‚Äôs not the solution for everything. 
Fixing the right problem should be the focus üëç 
Dilip Kumar Good post

UI alone won‚Äôt fix the lack of infrastructure or disrupt chronic diseases. But a well-designed user experience‚Äîone that aligns with users' digital learning curve and mental model‚Äîcan make health-tech advancements truly scalable, usable, and impactful.

UX in digital healthcare isn‚Äôt an afterthought; it‚Äôs the difference between adoption and abandonment. There‚Äôs a reason WhatsApp is ubiquitous‚Äîit works for people, not against them. We need healthcare solutions that do the same‚Äîsolutions that adapt to users, not ones that force users to adapt.¬†‚ú®

I think the bigger use cases of Tech / AI in Healthcare are in the non-consumer facing side. On the consumer side, as rightly pointed out it is more about augmentation. On the other hand, Tech can bring about disruption in the areas of drug discovery, clinical trials, radically improved therapies for life threatening conditions, diagnostics etc.
Before building the App one should understand how the healthcare system works on the Ground. Before building atleast once visit the hospital to know how the system works.

Very informative, Tech alone won‚Äôt fix Indian healthcare, where doctor shortages (1:1,511), poor rural access (600M people), and 20% counterfeit drugs persist. Unlike e-commerce, healthcare needs trust, continuity, and affordability not just AI chatbots or doctor-matching apps. The real opportunity is in augmenting care- scaling AI-assisted frontline workers, securing drug supply chains, and improving patient outcomes. Disruption won‚Äôt work, but smart, systemic upgrades will.

I have a question: When we say fix it! We presume it‚Äôs broken. 

What if we see the world as not broken but as something that‚Äôs evolving. 

When we see it as broken we reject it! If you break a bone, see the Dr. If it breaks twice, increase calcium and get healthier. 

If it breaks thrice, then go to a Therapist to understand what you need to do in your frequency. 

It‚Äôs evolution, healthcare needs to evolve to cover all aspects of health.
Tech is a commodity and accessibility & simplification of AI tools will commoditize it even further!
Great Line - "Don't over focus on AI without fixing the basics". Conceptualizes the entire discussion around AI.

text:
Gopi is right. The reality is brutal‚Äîless than 1% of aspiring athletes make it big, and even those who do are left with little security once their careers are over. Sports, like startups, have a power law distribution‚Äî10% of players make 90% of the money. Everyone else is a statistic.

We love to read and watch the underdog story‚Äîthe kid from nowhere who makes it to the top. But that‚Äôs survivorship bias. For every one success, there are tens of thousands who trained just as hard but got nothing. The real question is: why does sports have to be a gamble?

 If you‚Äôre not in the top 1%, you don‚Äôt get sponsorships, you don‚Äôt have financial security, and once your career ends‚Äîusually in your late 20‚Äôs or early 30s‚Äîyou‚Äôre left scrambling for what‚Äôs next.

In developed nations, sports is a structured industry. There are leagues, second-tier careers, college scholarships, and post-career pathways. 

If you don‚Äôt become an Olympic champion, you can still earn a living as a coach, analyst, trainer, or minor league player. The system doesn‚Äôt discard you the moment you‚Äôre not in the top 1%.

The problem isn‚Äôt that sports is hard‚Äîit‚Äôs that failure is absolute. An engineer who fails at a startup can get a job. A failed athlete? They often have nothing. That‚Äôs why in most countries without strong sports ecosystems, success in sports correlates with wealth. You can‚Äôt afford to be an athlete unless you can afford to lose.

Right now, telling a poor kid to pursue sports is like telling them to buy lottery tickets as an investment strategy. Until we change that, Gopi‚Äôs words will remain true. And that‚Äôs a failure‚Äînot of the athletes, but of the system.

A great sports system doesn‚Äôt just create champions‚Äîit creates a nation of resilient, disciplined, and competitive people. And that‚Äôs the foundation of real development.

text:
Building a business in preventive health is hard. No one tells you this upfront. I learned it the hard way, first as a founder, now as an investor.

You‚Äôve chosen the harder game. Not because prevention doesn‚Äôt work, but because people don‚Äôt pay for it. Most wake up thinking about chai, parathas , deadlines, and school fees. Not long-term health. People today want instant gratification‚Äîsugar today, gym tomorrow.

Curative health makes money because illness is urgent. No one postpones a bypass surgery or negotiates an ICU bill. But prevention?¬†Everyone hunts for gym discounts, coupon codes for healthy food and thinks twice before paying for a fitness program.

Hospitals & pharma companies thrive because they sell relief from suffering. And suffering is a guaranteed market‚Äîprevention is not.

That‚Äôs why venture money chases curative health‚Äîit scales fast with clear unit economics, solving problems people can‚Äôt ignore. Asking someone to eat better, sleep more, and exercise for a payoff 5‚Äì10 years later is like selling an FD over a lottery ticket. So accept this reality and build accordingly.

Yet, prevention is the hardest problem and the biggest untaped opportunity.
#1 Healthcare in India will shift to prevention-not because people suddenly care, but because not caring is becoming too expensive. 

#2 Your market isn‚Äôt TAM, it‚Äôs WTM (willing-to-pay market). Everyone should care about health, but few will pay for it.To go mass-market, make it cheaper than chai and as seamless as WhatsApp.

#3 If you‚Äôre selling prevention, reposition it. People don‚Äôt buy prevention. They buy status, performance, and convenience. Make it aspirational & competitive.

#4 Trust in health isn‚Äôt built overnight. People won‚Äôt change their habits because you raised venture money. You‚Äôre in the business of delayed gratification. That means slow &sustainable growth.

#5 If your product doesn‚Äôt make people healthier or keep them engaged long-term, the number of app downloads doesn't matter. Focus on retention, real outcomes and revenue‚Äînot GMV, DAUs or metrics to make a pitch deck look good. 

If you can do this, you won‚Äôt just build a business‚Äîyou‚Äôll change how India thinks about health. And that‚Äôs worth building for.

This post deeply resonates with me. As a founder of a preventive health startup back in 2018, I learned firsthand how hard it is to sell prevention in a world wired for quick fixes.

Having lost both my parents to chronic diseases, I‚Äôve seen the devastating impact of neglected health choices up close. The irony? People turn a blind eye to things until they become chronic issues‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs mental health, metabolic dysfunction, or lifestyle-driven conditions. And when they do act, it‚Äôs often driven by fear, not foresight.

Prevention isn‚Äôt just a business challenge, it‚Äôs a behavioral challenge. People take anecdotal evidence over data, ignore long-term risks, and only act when the cost of inaction becomes unbearable. The real shift will happen when prevention isn‚Äôt sold as ‚Äòhealthcare‚Äô but as status, performance, and convenience‚Äîthings people already prioritize.

If we want prevention to win, we have to meet people where they are. Make it frictionless, rewarding, and aspirational. Package it in a way that taps into what they already desire‚Äîconfidence, success, and longevity. Build for behavior, not just health outcomes. Because the real challenge isn‚Äôt making prevention work‚Äîit‚Äôs making people care before it‚Äôs too late.
Selling prevention is like convincing someone to buy an umbrella on a sunny day‚Äîit‚Äôs tough but necessary. Making it aspirational and accessible is the only way to drive real impact.

Absolutely agree‚Äîbuilding a business in preventive health is tough. But there's another challenge we often overlook: the way we define "healthcare" itself.

Today, most of what we call healthcare is actually disease care‚Äîreactive solutions rather than proactive well-being. Prevention isn't just a "good-to-do" habit; it's a way of life. And to make it mainstream, we need to rethink how it's positioned.

‚úÖ Wellness isn‚Äôt expensive‚Äîit‚Äôs misunderstood.
Preventive health can be as affordable as a monthly grocery budget. The real gap isn‚Äôt cost; it‚Äôs knowledge. This is where professionals, doctors, and health experts play a crucial role‚Äînot just in treatment, but in making prevention practical and attractive.

‚úÖ Behavior change isn‚Äôt about logic, it‚Äôs about desire.
Telling people to avoid unhealthy habits isn‚Äôt enough. Just like kids need a candy to build a habit, adults need incentives to embrace prevention. The best health solutions don‚Äôt just inform‚Äîthey inspire and integrate into daily life seamlessly.

If prevention is the future of healthcare, then professionals must sell what people want to deliver what they need. That‚Äôs how we shift from a reactive system to a truly preventive one.

While modalities like ultrasound, IFT, and TENS may provide temporary relief, they do not address the root cause of pain or dysfunction. True healing and long-term recovery come from a physiotherapist‚Äôs expertise in hands-on therapy, exercise prescription, and most importantly, preventive healthcare.
Physiotherapy is not just about treating pain; it is about preventing it. Regular assessments, posture correction, and guided exercises can help avoid chronic conditions, improve mobility, and enhance overall well-being. Investing in a physiotherapy consultation isn‚Äôt just about recovery‚Äîit‚Äôs about building a healthier, pain-free future.

Child obesity growth in India for last 25 years. Please don‚Äôt make your kids a profit machine to processed & packaged food industry. 27 million kids under the age of 18 are overweight or obese in India. 
We‚Äôve to fix it.

#1 Don‚Äôt outsource their health to the system. The government, schools, and corporations don‚Äôt care about your child‚Äôs health. You as the parent will have to take the responsibility.

#2 Play & sports is nature‚Äôs way of making kids fit. Kids are meant to run, climb & move. Don‚Äôt force them to sit for hours and then doom them to screen addiction.

#3 Parents think kids should ‚Äòwant‚Äô to exercise or eat well. But waiting for motivation is a trap. Set rules. No junk food in the house. Stock the kitchen with real food.

#4 The mainstream food industry is a trap. Ads target kids. It‚Äôs all designed for short-term profit at the cost of lifelong disease. Don‚Äôt wait for policy changes. Teach your kids to think independently about health. 

Your child‚Äôs health is a function of their habits, not their genes. Fix the inputs, and the outputs take care of themselves.

Dƒìha Training Studio: Revolutionizing Pain Management and Movement Optimization

At Dƒìha, we are building a cutting-edge personal training studio dedicated to healing and empowering individuals dealing with chronic pain, while helping them achieve optimal fitness.

Our unique approach integrates:

We understand that the site of pain is often not the root cause. For example, knee pain may stem from poor foot mechanics or limited hip mobility. Dilip Kumar, In partnership with CoReCo Technologies Private Limited, I am building a health app called 1Step.

It is essentially a technology implementation of the concepts presented in the book Atomic Habits by James Clear, applied to the personal health improvement context. We have come up with 20 atomic habits which can improve one's health, and dramatically if these habits are stacked on top of each other. These habits together constitute the '1Step Approach' and belong to one of 3 categories: 1) Build a Solid Foundation, 2) Strengthen the Body, and 3) Strengthen the Mind.

There are a couple of neat GenAI use cases in this app which we are implementing right now and will be live in a couple of months. And of course, ML will be required to 'hyper-personalize' the '1Step Approach' for every user.

1Step has 3 modules: Learn, Do, and Track.
1) 'Learn' module contains self-paced courses, live courses, and expert talks.
2) 'Do' module contains atomic habits to improve one's health (10 to begin with) as well as online classes (3 to begin with).
3) 'Track' module contains ways to track the changes that people go through when they start making changes to their diet, exercise, and lifestyle.

We are launching on 6-Jan-2025.

comments: Divya Dixit

It's great to learn and see healthcare startups coming up to solve health related problems.

However,  a dark side of healthcare startups is growing everyday.

One of the key aspects of healthcare is Patient Privacy and Patient data safety. Startups today are openly flouting the regulations by sourcing patient data (read potential customers) by illegitimate means.

They know about patient history, pan, aadhar details, payments made.

Then they push down complex treatments and surgeries down your throat as Candies.

Such low is the level they are bringing the healthcare down to. (Not that it was great anyway) but most doctors had humanity,  compassion and intent to help patients.

On the contrary, these startups are turning into commercial engines to please their bosses and investors with no regard and empathy to patient conditions.

I hope and wish you succeed as an investor with an empathetic approach towards end users (patients) and guide/educate your portfolio companies about importance of patient data safety, integrity.

Best wishes.

HAPPY ‚Äì HEART ATTACK PREVENTION PROGRAM YARDSTICK

Launch: The program was launched in a chemical Industry covering about 1000 employees on 08 Aug 2022.
Vision: To achieve Zero Heart Attack status
Principles:
1.	80% of MI (Myocardial Infarction) cases are preventable.
2.	What cannot be measured cannot be improved, thus risk scoring is important.
3.	Optimum Resource Utilization by triage (identifying and focusing on High-Risk cases). 
4.	Focus on enhancing metabolism through aerobic exercises, since Hypertension, Diabetes, Obesity and Dyslipidemia are classified as Chronic Manageable Metabolic disorders.

Steps: 
1.	923 employees underwent detailed medical covering all identified important risk factors of MI.
2.	A cumulative cardiac risk score was assigned to each participant as per their reports.
3.	Five categories were created in different colors based on severity scoring.
4.	Based on scores, 191 (21%) employees were identified as high-risk employees, those were in Severely high (5%), Severe (6%) and Moderate (10%) risk groups.
A timely and significant initiative, Dilip! I am very hopeful about the endless interdisciplinary possibilities it will offer for both care and cure.

My Experience from the Meetup Dilip Kumar

1.It wasn‚Äôt just about exchanging visiting cards but about exchanging meaningful thoughts and ideas. The discussions were deep and impactful.

2. Trust is the Currency of the Health Market
Building trust takes time and effort‚Äîit‚Äôs not something that can be achieved through quick wins or an Excel multiplication sheet. Authentic connections matter in this space.

3. Pitching to Patient Investors
Approach investors who understand your space and are willing to grow with you over the long term. They‚Äôre likely to stick around and add value beyond just capital.

3.Health solutions thrive in an ecosystem. Collaboration and partnerships are essential to create lasting impact and scale effectively.

text:
Being a parent is so underrated. Come home to a child who has no clue how busy your day was, how long you were stuck in traffic, how many meetings you did. All it expects is your undivided attention. 

You are left with no energy but your heart wants to win this before the day ends.

The only way to play this game is to stay healthy & fit. This is the only way you will be around your family as long as you want.

Totally agreed‚Ä¶ so true!!!
Interesting

i think the best gift we can give our kids is the time they deserve. sometimes we tend to indulge so much in career making that we forget the fact that their childhood is never coming back and so is our time with them and our chance to re-live the childhood. Being a parent myself I have started prioritizing my health than any thing else.

Some relationships are beyond ratings. These can heal and rejuvenate more than tax or drain. 

If I were to rewind 3 decades, a child can be the perfect panacea for a trying day, still is.
Health and fitness are important not just for ourselves- but for being present and engaged with the family.

Agreed a 100%.  Getting fit and healthy is the only way out.

Transformation.Studio:   We're experimenting with programming for parents specifically. Focussing on foundations more than high performance.

True. Balancing career ambitions with family time is no easy feat. At 49, with two young boys (ages 6 and 4) eagerly waiting for dad time after office hours, I often feel the tug-of-war between being a committed employee and a present parent. I'm learning that, sometimes, quality beats quantity. Even a brief 15-minute story time or a short play session, with no phone or distractions, can go a long way in creating those special memories. üíô
I can‚Äôt emphasize this enough‚Äîmy husband and I often find ourselves in deep conversations about how we can live healthier and more mindful lives.
This is so identifiable!! Health is your true wealth and all the more important when you have to balance work with kids and family!

When you are not fit or healthy. It has so much spillover on so many aspects of your life. 

I have literally spent the last 6 months carving a fitter self (mentally and physically) so that I am a capable parent, partner, employee, boss..

Lost 30kgs, started therapy, going regularly to the gym. Learned some lifelong skills w.r.t food, fixed sleep, started meditation. Focused on building extendable rhythms than habits.

I literally feel like a different human being and my kids can most definitely tell that I enjoy spending time with them and not doing it to check off a box.

It is 1 million % worth it.
