text:
Entrepreneurs and builders in healthcare, i've 15 words for you.
Prevent, don‚Äôt treat
Engage, don‚Äôt shout
Prove, don‚Äôt promise
Empower, don‚Äôt instruct
Simplify, don‚Äôt complicate

Will elaborate- 
Prevent, don‚Äôt treat ‚Äì Focus on preventive care, it‚Äôs where the future lies.
Engage, don‚Äôt shout ‚Äì Build meaningful conversations, not just sales 
Empower, don‚Äôt instruct ‚Äì Deliver users with knowledge, not rules or features.
Simplify, don‚Äôt complicate- Make staying health easy, not overwhelming.
Prove, don‚Äôt promise ‚Äì Focus on showing validation to your claims and not marketing. 

https://x.com/kmr_dilip
comments: As a doctor and now a founder of preventive healthcare company , I‚Äôd say though the preventive care is the way to go but the adoption currently is very limited . There‚Äôs a need to educate and make the patients / customers see value in shifting the focus from reactive to proactive care !
Empower is also the leadership characteristic instead of instructions empowering can give path to new idea's, different ways, thinking to get things done.

Totally agreed, Dilip!

There‚Äôs a growing need for preventive healthcare, and we‚Äôre building exactly that at Even. Often, our initial conversations with potential members require a lot of convincing and evidence that preventive healthcare is the way to go. People are accustomed to the traditional health cover model, which only pays for bills; so our features‚Äîlike free doctor consultations, tests, and specialist visits‚Äîcan seem too good to be true.

That said, there‚Äôs also been a progressive shift in healthcare conversations recently, which is a promising sign that companies building healthcare slowly and steadily are on the right track. üéà

Love this! This is the essence of what we are and here is what has happened in the process!

Focus is on preventing disease by optimising nutrition and lifestyle - and the body has treated its own ailments, as it is given the right foundation

We engage - gamefied the product so that users are driven to use the platform and thereby have benefitted

Prove - it has taken us 8 years - the body not a hardware product where testing cycles are just another bug fix

Empower - life happens, we give you the tools that is best for you

Simplify - Science is heavy, we translate it to actionables. 20% of the interventions can bring about 80% improvements. We pick the interventions that give the best results (based on peer reviewed science and out own data)

Check us out at sr.tn or feel free to reach out to me directly if you want to join or know more about the program!
I'm sure every non-clinical founder thought ü§î whether they are working on prevention or treatments, after reading this first line

Great advice for healthcare entrepreneurs! 

Another key is to prioritize patient-centered care and focus on improving outcomes, not just profits.

We at Roojh Health do agree and have built solutions empowering doctors and patients who constitute the basic unit of healthcare.                But India has long way to go to build a mature healthcare system which parallels advanced countries and which works for all patients. e.g. patients health awareness/education is low, doctors resist digitization. It will take a village.
Insightful

So true Dilip.    If I may add one more:

Listen, don‚Äôt preach, then react.

Engaging with your clients/patients must be a conversation, not a monologue.

They will tell you their needs and how to fix them.

Thank you for you post!
Shifting from treating to preventive care would be a game changer
Great advice
This is on point Dilip Kumar :)

Also 3D print Human parts first and the world has to get together to test them asap to benefit mankind.

I guess Dilip also a united front across all nations is required because the idiot friendly super power and obamacare also has unfortunately damaged mankind more than helped.
15 words, but a whole new mindset! Dilip Kumar
Very well said Nivesh Khandelwal

What you see is oartly and mostly due to the patients themselves demanding a treatment, a doc that does not prescribe a med is considered to be out of this world.
And so the ship chugs along.
And as someone has rightly said in your post line that let humans be humans‚Ä¶. 
Eat drink make merry ofcourse in moderation and as per individual appetite after all it is one life
Great insights! I would also add that personalized healthcare is the way forward.

Dilip Kumar Excellent principles! Focusing on prevention, engagement, empowerment, and simplicity is key to driving real change in healthcare. Proving value through action rather than promises is how impactful brands will stand out.

Engage, don‚Äôt shout
Prove, don‚Äôt promise
Empower, don‚Äôt instruct
Simplify, don‚Äôt complicate

This sounds like something all founders should do üòä
Sir please consider rural India were 75 percentage population live

Dilip Kumar 

The current healthcare market in India has long been reactive, centered around treatment rather than prevention, a strategy that has become outdated.

Giants like Apollo and Fortis have traditionally focused on curative care, but the future demands a strategic pivot. Startups like Curefit - house of cult and HealthifyMe App  are ahead of the curve, building their entire model around prevention, user engagement, and holistic wellness, which is proving to be more sustainable in the long run.

The shift to "prove, not promise" is key to long-term success. Practo‚Äôs user-review strategy exemplifies how validation and trust can become a competitive advantage.

As the healthcare landscape evolves, companies that adopt preventive care, empower users with knowledge, and offer simplified, user-friendly experiences will truly stand out.

Strategically, this isn't just a trend, it's a survival strategy for the future of healthcare.

Worth thinking about!
Absolutely agree. Prevention is key, and engagement is crucial Dilip
Better, don't worse. Thanks for summing this Dilip Kumar

So true. How about we look at sports as a way to show people that you can get healthier by actually playing some sport regularly, if gym isnt a thing? The sport could be running, badminton, run or maybe the latest craze in town - pickleball!
Well said! üëèüèΩ

Love this, Dilip Kumar!

1. Prevent, don't treat‚Äì Tech like wearables and AI make prevention easier and actionable.

2. Engage, don't shout‚Äì Personalize care through real conversations, not sales talk.

3. Empower, don't instruct‚Äì Simple, clear education builds trust and confidence.

4. Simplify, don't complicate‚Äì Keep tech intuitive so patients and providers focus on health, not complexity.

5. Prove, don't promise ‚Äì Show real-world results. Data and trials speak louder than marketing.

This aligns perfectly with the direction healthcare needs to take‚Äîthanks for sharing!

At Prevealth, we also believe the same- The future lies in the Preventive Healthcare. However, it requires a lot of attention on the human element. While prevention is better than the cure, a push is needed to change the mindset of people from reactive to preventive healthcare. 
Any suggestions on how to work on this?

¬†Focusing on prevention, engagement, and empowerment is key in building trust and delivering real value. Simplifying the journey to better health ensures that users aren‚Äôt overwhelmed but feel supported, while proving your claims solidifies your credibility in a space that thrives on evidence.¬†
This is so needed. The healthcare system needs to change and focus on simplifying processes and preventive care. Dilip Kumar

Healthcare entrepreneurs and builders, here are my 15 words for you:

Balance, don‚Äôt oversimplify 
Inform, don‚Äôt preach 
Adapt, don‚Äôt rigidify 
Validate, don‚Äôt exaggerate 
Engage, don‚Äôt ignore

Will elaborate:

Balance, don‚Äôt oversimplify ‚Äì Find the right mix of prevention and treatment, complexity and simplicity. 
Inform, don‚Äôt preach ‚Äì Provide knowledge and structure, not just one or the other. 
Adapt, don‚Äôt rigidify ‚Äì Be flexible and responsive to the ever-changing landscape of healthcare. 
Validate, don‚Äôt exaggerate ‚Äì Back up your claims with evidence, but don't forget the importance of marketing. 
Engage, don‚Äôt ignore ‚Äì Build meaningful conversations, but also convert that engagement into action. Dilip Kumar
Love this üëå

No one is apparently talking about preventive mouthcare, recently followed few dental hygienists _ in India no one is working well on prescriptive hygiene such a big gap in dental healthcare, which definitely affects your overall gut and digestive health.

text:
Have met over 600+ healthcare startups this year at Rainmatter. These are my general observations of the sector in 2024 so far. An investor & health enthusiast perspective. 

Remember, these are observations and not opinions.  If you‚Äôre a builder, I'm always keen to exchange notes.

1) Health tech needs maturing ‚Äì The novelty phase of tech meets health is over and the focus should be on driving outcomes to the user.

2) Preventive health is gaining traction ‚Äì More startups are focused on preventive solutions.

3) Nutrition personalisation is heating up ‚Äì Companies are going beyond generic consulting and leveraging DNA, microbiome, or other personal data for nutrition recommendations.

4) UPI for health not yet in India- ABDM use cases haven't seen much adoption.

5) Wearables are no longer the star ‚Äì Smartwatches and rings are still strong but are considered table stakes. Consumers want something that tells ‚Äúwhy‚Äù and not limited to ‚Äúwhat‚Äù.

6) Corporate wellness is an overrated market ‚Äì With rising mental health issues, stress, and burnout in the workforce, B2B wellness solutions ideally should show promise. But there isn‚Äôt adoption from corporates.

7) The ‚Äúbiohacking‚Äù trend is niche but growing ‚Äìlongevity startups are speculative but hot.  Increasing interest in biohacking protocols (sleep optimization, anti ageing etc.). But the market is niche and often hard to validate scientifically unless clinical protocols are done.

8) Consumer trust in health supplements is dwindling ‚Äì The supplement industry lacks regulation and transparency and this has eroded trust amongst consumers. Brands are focusing on science-backed products.

9) AI in healthcare ‚Äì Many are bullish on AI‚Äôs potential to revolutionise diagnostics, patient care, and drug discovery, but deployment in clinical settings is slow and capital-intensive.

10) Mental health is booming ‚Äì Digital mental health startups, especially those offering therapy, coaching, or CBT solutions are seeing adoptions but differentiation is becoming a challenge in a crowded market.

11) Community-driven fitness ‚Äì Social, community-oriented fitness solutions still have potential if done right especially those blending real-world interactions with digital offerings.

12) CAC is a challenge for D2C health brands ‚Äì Brands are facing rising customer acquisition costs often with no sustainable GTM.

13) Hybrid health businesses are scaling better ‚Äì Companies combining digital and physical services have better scope of scaling fast.

14) Telehealth plateaued ‚Äì The initial excitement around telehealth has subsided for both consumers and investors.

15) Health marketplaces have no moat ‚Äì Platforms connecting consumers with healthcare providers or wellness services are overrated with no clear moat to grow.

There are more thoughts on this. Because of the word limit on Linkedin , can't post the remaining here. Read the whole list on https://lnkd.in/g-CTY4zC

For the first time in two decades I‚Äôm seeing more 20 year olds saying I want to prioritise my mental & physical health than build wealth. The era of longevity has come a full circle.

Most people start seeing their health deteriorate in their 30s & beyond.

Becoming unhealthy is not an event. It is a process. Like losing money, losing your health is rarely caused by one thing going wrong. Usually, it is a series of ignorant and wrong doings.

No matter how much money you have, how many ESOPs you earned, how great your company‚Äôs valuation soared. 

If you can‚Äôt take a walk on a random Wednesday morning or eat your breakfast without checking emails.

You‚Äôre NOT wealthy.

It is time for organizations to also catch up. Some visionary companies have already started investing in the well-being of their employees, redefining what it means to care for their teams, often called "family." This is more than a trend - it is a necessary evolution in the way we work and live.

In the end, health isn‚Äôt just a personal responsibility‚Äîit is a collective one. If we can foster an environment where well-being is prioritized at all levels, both individuals and businesses can thrive together.

A lot of good can happen to India and our culture when more people play sports and that creates future athletes. There is a special emotion in seeing Indian flag on global sports map.

In all my conversations with professional athletes, the common request has been for consistent support for their pursuits‚Äînot just financial, but also cheering for their smaller wins and being on their side when they don't make it to the podium. 

India has the sports talent but we also need a support system and processes to guide and anchor these athletes continuously. We are excited to partner with the GoSports foundation, who are doing this and more towards athlete development and support.

Yesterday, we met a few Olympians and Paralympians, and all of them had a common goal- to make India proud. At Rainmatter by Zerodha we are cheering for them and the team at GoSports Foundation. 

Deepthi Bopaiah, Nandan Kamath

Your message reflects an important and inspiring perspective. 

Encouraging and supporting athletes in their journey, both in success and in times of struggle, is essential to building a robust sports culture in India. 

It's true that consistent support, not just financially but emotionally, can make a huge difference in athletes' lives. 

By recognizing and celebrating even the smaller milestones, we can create a strong ecosystem that fosters growth, resilience, and determination.

Your partnership with GoSports Foundation is a significant step in the right direction. 

Supporting organizations that focus on athlete development and creating long-term frameworks for their success can truly help India rise on the global sports stage. 

It's wonderful to see initiatives like Rainmatter by Zerodha contributing to this cause, and this collective effort will certainly help future athletes make the nation proud.

Cheering for Indian athletes in every step, whether they win or lose, will build a more inclusive and passionate sports community, and seeing the Indian flag shine globally brings immense pride to the country.

Back in the days buying milk was fun. Walk for 20mins to the booth. Exchange currency to get coins. Put each coin in the machine  and wait for the milk. Dilip this reminds me of Varghese Kurien, the legend who fought against bureaucracy for 3 years to introduce bulk vending.

Sharing an interesting story here - to implement Operation Flood successfully, Kurien wanted to import ~200 machines for Rs. 1.5 crore. However, this proposition was not passed by the government.

What does the man do? Builds his own vending machines in India with coins that work perfectly. Mind you, this is a time when coins wouldn‚Äôt always work in public telephone booths.

'Instant Commerce' aka smart vending machines/kiosks for sub INR 200 transactions could be the answer? üòÖ

It was fascinating to see milk being dispensed by a machine,the good old days.

I feel like I might be older, or perhaps my city didn't have milk vending machines back in the day. nostalgic!

Decoding the market for packaged foods in India. And why two IIT grads who went to Harvard and IIM wants to give you better options to eat healthy. 

In this podcast i‚Äôm talking to Ahana Gautam founder of Open Secret and Sudarshan Gangrade founder of Bajo Foods.  

This episode is a business breakdown on building a healthy eating category in India. Everything you should know about creating food products, understanding consumer behaviour, pricing, distribution , surviving and winning an extremely competitive market segment. 

Some numbers to give you context :
Package food industry in India will be $186 billion¬†market.
Chocolates is $3.8 billion & Snacks is $5.3 billion. 
Is there an opportunity to create healthier alternatives. 

Can new startups win consumer adoption in a market that is extremely competitive and has large incumbent players?¬†Why should India eat healthy?

Watch the full episode here https://lnkd.in/gyn6r5BY

Dilip Kumar

Key Points for the Podcast

1. Market Size: India's packaged food industry is worth $186 billion.  Chocolates and snacks are key segments, valued at $3.8 billion and $5.3 billion, respectively.

2. Opportunity: There‚Äôs room for healthier alternatives as consumer demand for wellness grows.

3. Challenges for Startups: Competing with established brands requires innovation in product quality, pricing strategies, and distribution.

4. Why Eat Healthy: Reduces lifestyle diseases, lowers healthcare costs, and promotes overall well-being.

Guests:

1. Ahana Gautam (Open Secret) and Sudarshan Gangrade (Bajo Foods) will share their experiences in creating healthy food options and navigating the competitive market.

text:
1.4 billion people and 117 athletes. This podcast is to understand Indian sports, governance & infrastructure. And how do we bridge the gap between potential and commitment to olympic aspirations.

I‚Äôm talking Deepthi Bopaiah, CEO of GoSports Foundation. She has spent many years in identifying and supporting talent for Indian sports.
This episode will tell you more about
-Sports governance  in India and how it works.
-Current infrastructure and what could be done to improve.
-Stories about women and parathletes in Indian sports you never knew.
-Toolkits for young athletes and their parents to pursue sports as professional career.
-And how we can create better systems to have more olympic medal potentials.

Watch the full podcast here https://lnkd.in/gYKVSwnJ

Do me a favour and please share it with an aspiring athlete or a parent who has dreams to make a kid play sports for India.
comments:
The Indian sports industry is still lagging behind, not due to a lack of investment in our elite athletes, but because of deficiencies in research and development, applied sports sciences, and the availability of top-notch, homegrown technical support staff. We remain overly reliant on Western coaches in most Olympic sports, which hinders the development of indigenous expertise.

At the grassroots level, the situation is even more concerning. The basic facilities necessary for nurturing future athletes are insufficient, and there has been a lack of comprehensive studies to address this. Rather than spreading resources thinly across all sports in every state, a more strategic approach is needed. We should focus on identifying which sports have the most potential in specific states and concentrate our resources there. This would involve targeted investment in states that naturally produce talent in particular sports, rather than wasting funds in regions where there is little interest or potential.

But, while the government and corporates can do a lot to improve infrastructure and standards, I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs going to change if we simply depend on institutions to help solve the lack of success.

There is a tendency for people to make general excuses such as genetics, diet, weather, poverty, infrastructure etc etc for why we don‚Äôt have more success. 

For each one of the above, there is a country or athlete that will have proven otherwise. 

Having coached kids in a sport, I have seen plenty of ‚Äútalent‚Äù gone to waste either from a change in priorities or from excuses mentioned above.

All key challenges and areas to work in Indian sports are well covered. Working with para-athletes like Suhas L.Y., Sumit Antil, Sundar Gurjar, and Shweta Sharma has provided deep insights into their daily struggles. I believe social media can significantly boost awareness for these athletes and promote other sports beyond cricket. There's widespread criticism of the BCCI for not supporting other sports, but we must remember who supported these athletes during their toughest times. text:
Bring a bunch of founders under one roof, let them talk to each other, give no gyaan. And magic will happen.¬†Last Friday was this. 
Did an impromptu Health Founders meet-up in Delhi last Friday. 180+ people signed up. Could only admit 40 due to space limitations. All of them showed up and few brought their co-founders along.

I thought events and meet-ups were in abundance. Maybe 5-10 people will turn up. But 50 founders were hanging out for 4 hrs on a Friday evening. And all passionate about health and building products to make Indians healthy. 

There was no speech, no panel, no agenda. 
But entrepreneurs have an innate ability to communicate.¬†So they all started talking to each other. Figured that networking is overrated. But a space to have unfiltered conversations and be your authentic is underrated. 

Some got new customers.
Some met their customers who were using their products. 
Some got offer to share the office space.
Some validated their new product ideas.
Some established new partnerships. 
Lot of questions on why, what and how. 
And a few made their funding pitch. Founder preamble you know :) 
There was learning and a some unlearning. 

Apologies for people we couldn‚Äôt admit. There was a genuine space limitation. 
It was an experiment and i dint expect this much response. 

At Rainmatter our credo is to add meaningful support to the ecosystem. 
Either through capital allocation or cheering for entrepreneurs. 
Should we do this more often? In other cities?

text:
Behind every star athlete or a champion there is a supporting family.¬†
Parents who teach their kids that success is not about winning but how well they can recover when they fall. 

This is Nagalakshmi. An unassuming mother of two young Indian chess prodigies Praggnanandhaa and Vaishali. The first-ever brother-sister duo to both earn the Grand master title. Today both of them are well known for their achievements in the sport. Most don‚Äôt know that their mother, Nagalakshmi accompanies them to tournaments for encouragement and support. Father Rameshbabu works as a branch manager at TNSC Bank and is honest to say they were facing financial constraints but were determined to support both their kids. 

I‚Äôve now spent time with Olympians, World champions & India no.1 on my podcast and a common thread amongst all of them is their early childhood and the parental support all of them had.¬† The most important economic decisions a society makes are not made in corporate offices, but in homes.
https://x.com/kmr_dilip

text:
Have met 500+ startups solving for health, nutrition & fitness in last 12 months at Rainmatter. There is an opportunity no one is looking at. My thoughts....

Those building tech mostly tell HOW is the sleep, blood glucose , calories, HRV , recovery and more. Your current baseline. That's the current generation of wearables. 

But no is telling WHY it's happening. 
I think this will be the future of health wearables. 

Those building food products claim THEY are healthy & better. 
But no one is telling WHY they are better.

I think solving for WHY will unlock new market opportunities . 
How & What will get you first time customer. 
Why will get you lifetime user.

Usecase: If the RHR (resting heart rate) suddenly spikes, we should know why.
If the HRV dropped, we should know what caused it.

Shared some other opportunities earlier here https://lnkd.in/gn6ibaGj
comments:
Perhaps your community might also be interested in the
#GreenShoots Startup Pitch Competition by Gulfood Green...

...Pitch Lounge are co-producing the pitch event, and all the key information is available on our website here:

www.pitchlounge.net/green-shoots

INFO SESSION this week:

https://lnkd.in/giK7F7-U

Taking this train of thought a step further, I feel like the interpretation of the data and research involved wrt improvement in fitness causes a lot of friction for people pursuing any fitness goal. 

Along with the HOW biomarkers are changing and WHY they are, if there was a way to continously suggest areas of improvement and tactics from personalized data collection, it would remove a great deal of friction from the process and possibly increase adherence.  

I believe this is done on a case by case basis by personal trainers and nutritionists now, but could be done on a larger scale with the right methods to collect the personalized data. (Mostly because finding good nutrionists and personal trainers who are trustworthy is hard, which I exactly what believe Fittr is solving)

PS: Will it be possible for you to share the 500+ companies solving for health/fitness in a repository of some sort?, I'm sure it would be helpful for a lot of us.
Health is not a mere sum total of all parameters neither is nutrition a sum total of all ingredients

Out of the 500+ startups, have you come across a startup which offers a holistic solution combining the following in a single app -
1. Basic exercises/strength training 
2. Yoga and meditation 
3. Diet/nutrition .. ??
My sister, a plastic surgeon, has an idea to build an interesting AI-driven application along these lines.

Dilip Kumar We'd love the opportunity to be 501+ on that list of healthcare startups you've spoken to! We believe we're solving for something big, that can bring together consumer health screening and tracking into a single powerful app that can give clues as to the WHY of health!

I believe, to know why something is happening in your body , you need to have AI with you 24 hours everyday, always listening to you, always watching you. Knowing almost everything you are doing everyday and everything happening everyday with you. For example: That tech should know that today you have some fierce talk with your wife and you are upset or today you got your salary with a bonus and you are surprisingly happy, literally everything it should know to give you the best answer for why or how there are any good or bad changes in your health or could happen, or there is any room to make the things better. 

There should be an AI chip implanted in the brain that can analyse the neurological links, process it and send required output to your wearable devices. Or maybe something similar which can tell almost everything about you and feed that data to AI. 

Best of luck to those who are going to make such Advanced and Accurate AI, but even if it gets developed , there would be many hurdles to get it positioned in the market. üëç

That's a brilliant insight!

At Cranberry, we are building with the WHY for women's health. Our learning - we need robust health protocols which can point us to the probable causes, every data point captured OR shared should have a back story or future (preventive) :). We are also keen on making these health protocols - open source - as we truly believe with need more people sharing WHYs over magic solutions and graphs.
Also the wearables should reach diagnostic grade.

And the WHY need not be technology based - it could even be consultation with specialists based on the HOW and WHERE info that's collected already. (If the info collected via wearables is not sufficient to figure out the Why, it could narrow down the diagnostic journey by having only the required tests done)

I'd also assume, that'll make it easier to go another step further to provide corrective measures and changes that need to be implemented to course-correct (WHAT Next?)
Saraswathi Mopuru FYI

Will there be an adoption if there are solutions for why because people are then equipping themselves with methods of self healing, and discovering alternate ways of staying fit in the long run. 

Totally bullish on brands building a solid consumer narrative to give them access to this new information

My view , "Why not?" Can lead us to a better opportunities and experiences.

Also, Whoop has a Beta Coach imbibed in the app, and I can ask what all things caused the spike or drop and it gives me a quick inference, Though generic but I think pretty soon we‚Äôll get there !

I mean I'd absolutely love such a service but kind of skeptical about it's reliability.

Curious to hear your take

Your insight on the untapped potential of "WHY" in health tech and nutrition is spot-on. While current solutions focus on the "HOW" and "WHAT," addressing the underlying reasons behind health data and product benefits is key to creating lasting value and building lifetime users.

Dilip Kumar   Solving the "WHY" would be an Herculean task as there would be more than 8 billion unique use cases mapped to world population...tech giants need to collaborate to arrive at such an 'utopian dream' solution

I see why the WHY matters and brings a big opportunity. It creates more value for the user and the businesses. Leveraging data science to unveil the WHY is like generating actionable insights rather than just providing plain data/metrics.

Once the WHY is known, possible solutions and recommendations then become viable to be tested out against that WHY.

Hi Dilip,

We, at Ariso, are building for ‚Äòwhy‚Äô certain foods suit some people and doesn‚Äôt suit the rest. Generally we are solving for food opacity and depersonalised food shopping and simultaneously answering the ‚Äòwhys‚Äô.

Would love to have a chat with you Dilip Kumar!

To achieve a deeper understanding of health and wellness, rigorous validation through RCT studies, advanced biometric analysis, and interdisciplinary collaboration are essential. By uncovering the WHY behind changes in health metrics, we can unlock new market opportunities and empower users for lifelong wellness. Great insights Dilip Kumar

Look at the meaning of the root words for #Health and #Holistic, you will get your answer. 

We aren‚Äôt Holistic in fullest sense in our approach and hence the problems (read lost opportunities). 

#HolisticMatters when it‚Äôs matter of #Health.
Dilip Kumar rightly said

Interesting observation. I would think that growth of ‚ÄúHow‚Äù will build the market for ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù. In simpler terms, tracking the metrics will pique people‚Äôs interest in knowing why metrics are behaving in certain way. Once the market of ‚ÄúHow‚Äù reached a certain scale then automatically either the same companies will build on ‚Äúwhy‚Äù or new companies working on ‚Äúwhy‚Äù will come up.
Solving for WHY from HOW is not just a keyword change.

Neuphony‚Ñ¢  can help figure out ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù - by tracking neural triggers / map your brain‚Äôs signals as a reaction to some of these products. They also have a wearable device (smartwatch for the brain). They did a small experiment with a healthy tea brand. Tech is evolving quickly :) Dilip Kumar 

Ria and Bhavya love talking about it! :)
Very well articulated Dilip Kumar. Unless we investigate and understand what really caused that specific psychological change, most interventions are just a band aid.

Dilip Kumar thanks for sharing your thoughts openly, I am building a Lifestyle Functional food company and one of our angle is to understand the ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù in Modern Health issues and Formulate our products on the basis of that. Your post gives me a positive thought that we are moving in the right direction. If given a chance I would like to talk more about it with you .

As someone who digs for WHYs when it comes to health and nutrition related stuff, I have been surprised by people not caring enough for the WHYs.

People who seek the WHYs are in minority is what I feel. Resulting into orgs not focusing on them?

What this requires is building the medical repository to be used as reference. When we started Muse Diagnostics focussed on sound based diagnostics we realised the importance of creating sound repository that allows for every sound to be able to diagnoses from a reference guide. We should talk more because we are working in this witj sound based diagnostics as a use case.

Hey Dileep,

Great insights! At WTF Gyms , we're on the same wavelength. Our app doesn't just track metrics; it explains the 'why' behind them. We're leaping ahead, focusing on nutrition, daily workouts, and essential body metrics. It's about showing members where they start on day 1 and guiding them towards their goals, spotlighting what's changing and why. This approach is already making a difference for us.

Absolutely agree with you ‚Äî understanding the 'why' is crucial. It's not just about finding the reason but sticking to it and ensuring it doesn't become just another statistic. Your thoughts have sparked even more ideas for us, and thanks to this, we're excited to soon offer the WTF app to non-subscribers too. We want everyone to benefit from our scheduling system, nutritional guidance, and core tech features.

Looking forward to building on these ideas and enhancing our community's health journey!
To say ‚ÄòWhy‚Äô confidently one needs strong ethics, genuine intent and a sense of responsibility.

I have a different point of view. Most folks care about only outcomes. So long as there is a basic explanation on how food and the human body work, it‚Äôs sufficient to bring awareness. Likewise all analytical tools only tell you if things are going right/wrong. The hardest challenge is behaviour changing for sustainable health. This is a complex problem being influenced by childhood behaviour, work, family, environment, physiology, emotions etc. The ones that benefit from say RHR, HRV are the ones who are already deeply into fitness and health. Likewise for the ones who care about understanding stuff from first principles. It‚Äôs a lot like the difference between being a chef , a cook and the vast majority that just want someone to give them tasty food.

Understanding origin & progression of disease ( THE WHY) is the key. However, there is huge gap before wearables could decode. The current wearable tech is nothing but a small pie in disease management opportunity.

 For instance, CGM can tell you spike in blood glucose/blood sugar response/levels. But this does not help until we have info & data on GLUT 4- the protein that goes to cell membrane, bind to glucose, clear it from circulation & transport to cell for storage or energy. Therefore data on molecular signalling that activates GLUT 4 is the key.

Similarly, we may know HRV but unless we decode /measure norepinephrine and epinephrine levels or histamine signalling, HRV is of no use

If I am remember correctly, we had a brief call with your team a month back but I think there was gap in understanding our business model/ or the call was more of idea/innovation shopping.

In my experience building an Electronic Health Record(EHR) this is extremely difficult to implement.

Here's why: Root cause diagnosis has to be done by General Medicine doctors and not specialists because only root cause can tell exactly "Why" and this is how the process would flow for that:

Chief Complaint/Symptom
Clinical Finding
Differential Diagnosis
Chronic conditions(if any)
Genetic conditions(if any)
Social Behaviours that can cause a condition
Allergies
And Lab Tests to validate

All these factors are necessary to know WHY. Now am assuming that you don't want it to exactly be a 100% but if it's not atleast "quite accurate" then the "Why" can scare the customer especially since most of the these wearables have a lot of inaccuracies. And having all this data captured by a wearable or otherwise is an expensive affair in my experience.

And most importantly the "Why" is difficult even for a doctor to find. That's why it's called a Differential Diagnosis. #myexperience

You are right. My view. I have studied many Healthy food products of USA. Many of them are doing proper research and making healthy food involving science in it. But at the same time, it is equally important to convey to the customer which they are doing beautifully.
Why and What product is doing has to be true and conveyed properly to the customer.

I think the WHY for a certain bodily reaction is going to be difficult because the body is a complex machine and multiple things can trigger the same reaction. For example: The cortisol can rise due to a life threatening situation or just work stress.

In my humble opinion, another opportunity that's big is in educating what bodily reactions are problematic, if not managed for a long time, and how they can be managed or reduced in the future.

Interesting take. I've had a chance to think a bit deeply on this (not as much however as I want to!) - and please take this with a grain of salt. 

I think research backed, innovation-led health startups are the future that solve ONE critical thing. Or co-related things. 

Example, there is a company solving for UTI diagnostics, they're created a completely new method for it. Another company is finding absolutely new ways to diagnose breast cancer early on. 

Finding the WHY requires research. Diabetes is still a myth, and I've always thought that businesses building around it should have a content gameplan that increases awareness around their solution.
Why can also be messaging/positioning angle for a business to differentiate

Hi Dilip
By WHY are you referring more on end results a consumer trying to achieve?
My observations being: 40+ age bracket is ready to invest in health but isn't looking for being muscular. 
Some of the products that are targeting this segment is trying to reduce medicine intake 
The reduced cost of medicines is a straightaway value observed 
Please correct if my understanding is incorrect
The WHY will need deep investments in biotech!

Instances backed by cause and resolution is what I see as the future of health especially from a consumer's lens. Today I spend atleast 2hrs a day reading about certain causes and solutions and then go through a trial and error with my body also because each body is different and a cookie cutter model can't be applied.
Dhaneesh

text:
Failures, medals, Olympics.  
And the journey to become India number 1. 


In this podcast I‚Äôm having a conversation with Prannoy HS . He is an Arjuna award winner currently ranked number 1 player in Badminton singles in India. And will represent the country in 2024 Olympics. 

But his journey has been a roller coaster with injuries and failures. And the comeback to winning medals is a fascinating tale of grit & determination. He has been one of the architects for winning the Thomas cup & Commonwealth games gold medal. 

In this podcast we discussed 
- Early years in Badminton and the pursuit to become a champion player 
- How parents can play a role in creating future olympians. 
- Coaching with Gopichand and career winning moments
- How professional athletes train and manage life.
- Managing stress & mental health.
- Building sports culture in India
- Failures and lessons from it
- And more

Spotify: https://lnkd.in/g-KUy5cy

text:
Can you make people healthy & fit and make a business out of it? Yes, you can. 

In this podcast, I‚Äôm talking to Jitendra Chouksey,¬†founder of FITTR.¬†

text:
An unpopular opinion about founders/VC's building and investing in health category. This may disappoint a few.

First, if you are a founder building in the health. You've to walk the talk. 
What does that mean? You have to be healthy and fit. 

-The biggest moat in the health industry is trust. This can't be built by performance marketing or hiring influencers. 
-Why will a customer trust your product if the founder isn't healthy? You don't need six packs. But you shouldn't look unfit.
-If your product came out from your own problem statement, great. Tell the world how you got there and share your experience. 
-In health industry you scale by not selling features. But by earning the trust. 

Second, don't pitch or raise money from an investor who doesn't walk the talk. 

-To build a scalable business TAM is important. But impact is most important.
- If the first question they ask is, how large is the business and not why you choose to build the product. That's a sign.
- If an investor doesn't make an effort to experience your product or service and offer genuine feedback. They are truly not investing in you. But chasing vanity.
- Have seen many VC events ending with alcohol and the food corner filled with junk. And that happens because they don't walk the talk and perhaps staying healthy is not their top priority in personal life. 

That's it. Hope this changes. And we build businesses and products that brings impact on people. And trust is your anchor to scale.

Being a healthy founder sets the tone for your team and reflects dedication to your mission.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-03-13 06:10:09', 'relative': '1 year ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1710306609613}
text:
32000 people have added "Career Break" and 53000 added "Sabbatical" as their current position on Linkedin. 

Most common description is " Working on my health & fitness" 
How did we get here?
comments:
I am in that stage now. Not for the health and fitness but to explore and acquire skills sets. 

It‚Äôs a trade off.

I am hopeful of net positive outcome.
Break is good for well being. Helps with pause and planning.

While running through the race of life, most of us have forgotten that a marathon is not a combination of multiple sprints - its a long long race, just like life and it requires lot of practice, lot of inner work, lot of rest, strength & stamina. 
‚ÄúHealth is & should be the priority‚Äù and the best part is, if you make it a priority, it doesnt stop you from focusing on other priorities - infact it becomes a seamless enabler.
Poor nutrition. Proinflammatory diet.

HR function and its practitioners ARE becoming progressive and pragmatic.

Meanwhile, it is ESTD (easier said than done!) for job-seekers to highlight career breaks and the reasons behind them.
Expectations + frustration üòî
It's good to see that Companies are also supporting this. If the strained employees have a backup of going back to the job after 6-8 months, then taking this decision becomes easier.

Even I have taken a career break and I would say that was the best decision of my life.
Instead of running in a race where you don't know the end goal, it's great to take a pause, reflect on what you really want to do and then resume. An arrow can be shot only by pulling it backward and 'holding' it for a moment.

9/10 people who fill out my coaching form list "Work" as the main stress. Lack of boundaries for work, work calls. We don't realise that email can wait.

Dilip Kumar

COVID helped people realise that health is ineluctable. 

One's career and money can be made eventually but health once lost cannot be recovered easily.
Due to the ignorance, and not paying attention to it on a daily basis!
Yes! I am one of them! Well I traveled and authored a book. Very rewarding experience.

You can actually not take break from work and still be "working on your health & fitness".

You just have to change your unhealthy lifestyle and dietary habits to healthy habits. Here are  some examples of healthy lifestyle habits-
Quality sleep.
Effective stress management.
Drinking 3-4 litres of water daily.
And most of those working on Health, are most likely to be working on their ‚ÄúMental Health‚Äù
Amazing mangers, beautiful work culture and supportive colleagues got us here ü§´

Maybe the awareness that a gap in CV is not as terrifying as the society has conditioned us to believe and there are more important things to life apart from career (health and fitness) which require full time focus. This is assuming a lot of damage has already been done because of ignorance to health/lack of awareness.

One of the core reasons is reinventing oneself.

With AI and emerging tech (and supersmart young minds), merely upskilling is not enough. You must reinvent yourself periodically and it happens by taking a step back and asking really basic (read dumb) questions about why you do what you do and why you're the right person to do it. And, sabbaticals help a lot here I guess. 

Let me come back and comment if it really helped. Because I heard someone saying ‚Äì there is a fine line between bravery and stupidity (and can only be realized by looking at the outcome üòÄ)
The real reason is return to office.
I just read Soni Shaw 's post that had a 24 year old die of a heart attack thanks to a hustle-heavy start-up. I am not surprised we reached here.

Earlier people with single income household were not able to do, given the family responsibilities. But that is now changing with double income households and also with more awareness on personal financial planning. 

And these planned breaks are helping to analyze own core values and purpose. And also helping to understand our priorities. 

Stepping back and looking on what progress we have made till date and which direction we want to go further is a good way to live life aligned to our true self.
Rise in disposable income and lesser financial responsibilities might be the reason for the increase.
Got definition of success wrong. peer pressure, societal pressure to chase wrong metrics esp as a man. stressful travel time, food habits, lack of time to exercise. its a vicious circle.

I decided to take a year-long career break to work on my mental and physical wellness, amongst other things. 9 months in, it has been the best decision of my professional life, and I've been feeling more mentally stimulated and energetic than ever.
Better its is rather than showing fake experience..
I did the same too...Needed to work on my health too
And these are the people who are bold enough to put it out publicly, many would not have done it... so the actual number would be higher than this...
Wow! Inspiring to see how much people value life as a whole. It's no longer about promotions and titles anymore. Well-being > External validation, love it! üëè
I will be doing same from May for sometime, though I don‚Äôt know the duration yet
It's captivating to witness this change in perception.
Something very serious to ponder about :)

Did you factor in the overlap XD. 
What is your intention with "How did we get here?". Is it a good thing or you think this is a concern? Dilip Kumar

We were already there, it's just that we have generated the courage to accept t that It's time. Breaking free from all the conditioning and manipulation all these years and trying to look within. 

PS: Enjoy your sabbatical folks, it's amazing to do absolutely nothing and yet be blissful all the time.

Easier said than done - but trying to answer one question genuinely, honestly as early as possible "What is the purpose of my life" may help. Finding the right balance between Ikigai - what you love > what the world needs > what you be paid for > what you are good at... finding the right balance between these four aspects is challenging
The world order is changing, earlier it was like you studied for 10+2+3/4/5 years and chose your career where you worked for 10/20/30 years. The technology shift is so fast now that what you learnt in the past 4-5 years is no longer relevant when you enter the job market...learn > unlearn > relearn needs to happen fast.

What do you mean by "get here" Dilip? From "where" are you referring to? 

Also, are you suggesting this is a good or bad transition?
Within sometime we will see people claiming as expert in "Career Break/ Sabbatical planing"...

I think this will start changing slowly. The last few decades have been people working tirelessly and only taking a break when mentally and physically exhausted and feeling purposeless - hence ‚Äúcareer breaks‚Äù.

People have now started realising the importance of health and therefore managing it better WHILE working hard! So this trend of career breaks might actually be going down in years to come - though not completely eliminated, which is how it should be!

The stats reveals our modern work culture
First came the hustle culture; work for 80 -90 hrs/week and then people are taking sabbaticals and career breaks to catch up on health and fitness..I am being reminded of the Hare and Tortoise story much too often..The Hare sprints and then takes rest to catch its breath while the tortoise cruises along slowly and steadily.. Seems like the modern world fantasizes the hare a lot more than the tortoise.. Age old wisdom have turned upside down!¬†

Can speak for myself. I took an 8 month long career break last year to legit work on my 'mental health and fitness'. It has helped, a lot and should be normalised. No need to be constantly running. Sometimes, a little pause is ok. Helps you get perspective.
Quite a revelation! somehow the general belief is that taking care of health is time consuming which is what deters most of us to focus on it - hope it changes soon.
Prioritizing work over self because the fear of falling short of money is anxiety provoking. What most fail to realize is that when they look after their self, they can work better.
Thanks for uncovering this!
It will increase more in coming times. Stopping and analyzing what you really want to do is important rather than running with no goal. I am one of them.

text:
73% of Indians are deficient in protein & over 80% of the population does not meet their daily protein requirements. There is a $2billion market opportunity in dietary supplements in India.

So do people really need supplements? Who is buying and why?

I sat down with three entrepreneurs building products and brands in this space -Samit Gupta of Neulife Nutrition , Pranav Malhotra of Trunativ & Shashank Mehta of TheWholeTruth. 

We discussed what it takes to build a business in nutrition category, how do consumers know what is genuine and fake, setting manufacturing, R&D capabilities, pricing , sourcing and growth opportunities in health foods and more.

If you are an enthusiast of consumer products or keen to build for the health market, this episode will have many takeaways for you.

Links to full podcast
Youtube: https://lnkd.in/gyPGxaYP
Spotify: https://lnkd.in/gDrjHCyp
Apple: https://lnkd.in/gC8CERqG

Obviously when u sit with entrepreneurs, they will vouch for the demand of the market mostly. If you would have sat with doctors, nutritionists - the discussion would have happened on the basis of customer centric and market potential.

Dilip Kumar - In the energy space, proteins represent  Power. 
What proteins do is that they grow and repair tissues. 

In the energy healing realm, we believe they strengthen and empower. Without proteins, we feel powerless or victimized by life‚Äôs ups and downs. 

Consuming more protein than needed signals that you‚Äôre out of touch with your inner power or you‚Äôre doubting your ability to cope with life‚Äôs issues.

The diet is the core of your health / fitness. People these days like to pop pills for everything. I am NOT against supplements but that can not be the starting point.
Samit Gupta amazing insights

A fun fact for everyone , the food we eat is first available to microbes in the mouth who predigest the food and makes available for it‚Äôs absorption in small and large intestine. Excess protein reaches gut where microbes living there ferment protein into harmful metabolites that trigger range of diseases. Pushing protein is just a way for supplement company to push their sales. Citation : https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7657053/.   ; https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36524472/#:~:text=Abstract,modulation%20of%20adrenergic%20receptor%20signaling.

I'm no expert..but just from experience, I've found that fiber plays a far more important role for me than protein. My gut health improves and this makes me feel lighter and much better during my workouts.

A good coach can change the game. A great coach can change the life. 


I met Prannoy HS last week and we did a podcast together. 

One topic we discussed a lot was about coaching. It‚Äôs a tool that many people don‚Äôt use much. Wether you are an athelete, entrepreneur, working professional or just anyone who wants to find the best in you. You need a coach. 

You don't know what it means to be great unless you have a coach besides you. 

Prannoy & Gopi has a special relationship that is beyond Badminton. I‚Äôm glad we sat down to unpack this and more. 

My takeway- The progress in your goal is the gap between your desire and commitment. The coach is your tool to measure it meaningfully.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-02-01 04:50:44', 'relative': '1 year ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1706759444595}
text:
Because some people admire Hrithik Roshan. So listen up!


Becoming unhealthy is not an event. It is a process.
Like loosing money, loosing your health is rarely caused by one thing going wrong. Usually, it is a series of ignorance and wrong doings. 
Take control now.
comments: Truly resonate, Dilip Kumar! It's very important to start today, for a healthier tomorrow!!

Good insights Dilip Kumar 

but his speaking rate is faster then my resting rate üòÅ
Whoa!! Whaaaatt!!
When you have the same resting HR as Hrithik ü§ùüòÄ
Good share üëçüèΩ
Thanks for sharing Dilip Kumar
Becoming unhealthy is definitely a gradual process that requires continuous attention and care. It's important to take control of our health before it's too late.

The insights on resting heart rate are intriguing. I've also found the resting respiratory rate (number of breaths per minute) to be an interesting number. Humans, with a rate of 12-20 breaths/min, enjoy a lifespan of 70-80 years. Dogs, at a swift 30 breaths/min, average 10-15 years. Turtles, with a slow 1-10 breaths/min, boast a century-plus lifespan.

This interplay between physiology and lifespan is super fascinating. If truly our heartbeats and breaths are limited, then athletic performance & meditation go a long way to help increase our lifespan. I believe there is tremendous power in slowing down your resting heart rate and respiratory rate.

Dilip Kumar
Thanks for sharing this!!

I can send it to my friends who smoke a lot!

Well said Dilip. The beneficial atomic habits add up to incremental benefits over time. The reverse is very much true. Don't let others take the driver's seat of your life. Take charge now. 
Some start a habit and then lose motivation.
The pain of discipline is uncomfortable.
But the pain of regret is unbearable.

It's not just about the cigarette; it's also about mental health. The way we cope with stress, workloads, and pressures determines the habits we develop. People often smoke seeking relief from feelings that, in a way, are slowly harming them. Smoking and alcohol are not solutions. When you, as an individual, suppress your pain, you may become depressed. Coupled with alcohol and cigarettes, it further deteriorates health. It's better to express yourself.

You make some thoughtful points about health being a gradual process rather than a single event. I agree that maintaining good health requires ongoing positive choices, rather than just avoiding one bad decision. Your advice to "take control now" is motivating - small, sustainable changes done consistently can make a big difference over time. However, it's also important to have compassion for oneself and others. Progress isn't always linear and there are many complex factors that affect health. Overall though, striving to make wise choices each day, while being patient with ourselves, can help foster wellbeing.

20+ years in sports. Oldest player in the history of tennis to be World rank 1. 
This is a special podcast with Rohan Bopanna. 


I sat down with Rohan just few days before he left for Australian Open. This conversation is not just for sports enthusiasts but for anyone who wants to get peak performance in life.

Rohan is redefining sports with his perseverance, consistency and mental strength. In his own words that's his toolkit to success. He is 43 year old and competing and winning at this elite level has never been done in the history of the sport. 

Full podcast on
Youtube: https://lnkd.in/giNUCu59
Spotify: https://lnkd.in/g9Tmu987
Apple: https://lnkd.in/gbhWiTUT

We discussed mental models for peak performance in life, how he overcame failures and setbacks, managing stress, his mental & physical training routine, support system we need build a sporting culture in India, parenthood and much more. 

It's a 2 hr long conversation like most of my podcasts üòä.  So give time to learn and absorb from one of the great athlete of all time.

text:
Founders, never let the investors be the judge¬†of your passion and commitment.


Missing good investments is the occupational hazard of venture capitalists.
One of the biggest learning in the past year after talking to 200+ founders is , investors can never estimate the insight a founder has to the problem statement they are solving for. A phone call or a coffee meeting will never be enough. 

Founder's superpower is the ability to understand user problems and build solutions that customers may not even ask for. And investors should let curiosity anchor the conversations than making conclusions based on reports or industry thesis. You may still not get it. That's fine. When you're a VC, not all bets are winners ‚Äì some are just lessons.

Btw, the market cap for Tesla today is $753 billion :) 
This excerpt is from Bessemer Venture Partner anti portfolio page.
comments:
Founder! Let your passion burn. 
Not VC doubts. 

Build that solution users crave. 
Not investors predict.
Dilip Kumar

Loved it. üòä 
Absolutely, loved it.

Investors should embrace curiosity and deeper conversations to truly appreciate a founder's passion and insight. It's not just about reports; it's about connecting with the essence of what they're building
Very interesting Dilip Kumar
Right Dilip, always consider every rejection as God's redirection..

VC/Angel and Founder(s) relationship is akin to the Parent-Child relationship. 
If the Child needs help, Parent should offer it, else help them get the help from outside. And as a Child, they shouldn‚Äôt seek the help unless absolutely necessary. 
That‚Äôs how the whole ecosystem will grow and flourish.
Good stuff!

posted_at: {'date': '2023-12-06 06:36:25', 'relative': '1 year ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1701840985240}
text:
23 million girls in India drop out of school annually due to a lack of proper menstrual hygiene facilities.

More than 300 million women in India still don't have access to proper menstrual hygiene products. And still use old rags, ash, leaves & clothes. 

Was talking to Vikas Bagaria yesterday to understand the current situation. 

While brands will do their bit to build awareness. The biggest impact will happen when we start talking about it at home, office and in social circles. 

-Celebrating one women's day in a year doesn't do any good. 
-Men should be comfortable in breaking the silence and engage in conversations with their daughter, sister, spouse & friends. 
-Menstruation education should be everyone's business. Awareness amongst girl child is good. But should be equally important amongst young boys. 

Ignorance is the real taboo. Menstruation education is a collective responsibility. 
This video came up later internally and thought it's apt to share here.
comments: Onpery¬Æ I think your recent post on inclusiveness and your #meninmenstruation
Karun Gopinath Pranab Kulkarni Harsh Saraswat
Dilip, I am glad we had this chat yesterday on the present situation of Menstrual Hygiene in India. We definitely need more men to come forward and make this into regular chats.

We did a Menstrual Health Survey recently - 68% women felt uncomfortable talking to male members in the family. Less than 7% were taught about menstruation in schools. 

Educate in Schools - so boys and girls get the right conditioning from their childhood. 

Empower in Families - so we all know it is nothing to be ashamed of

I was always shy to talk about menstruation, pads, and cramps with my father. Why? You can call it social conditioning. But, now I have a daughter, who is but very young. So, now I am sensitizing my husband. When the time comes, may he be empowered to support his little girl. Every family needs to come together to break this taboo and stigma.
so beautiful .... though my dad was very open to this discussion ....my neighbourhood/society wasnt .. i had to figure out so much myself
Such an important topic to be discussed with daughters. Thanks for sharing the video Dilip Kumar

What a beautiful post Dilip Kumar. My daughter, almost 12 years now, speaks very openly to me about cramps, pantyliners, brand choices etc. We started our conversation with Aditi Gupta's book https://www.menstrupedia.com/. Menstrupedia gave her the confidence to be ready and also talk about it openly with me and also with her cousins and friends. It builds a different Father- Daughter bond.
1000%. We‚Äôve been in that fight from the start and continue to push for better solutions for one part of it, Primary and secondary dysmenorrhea. Happy to share notes.

text:
Employee wellness needn‚Äôt be complicated. 

That‚Äôs Nithin, Vishnu & me crossing the finish line at IronMan Goa last month.
We participated as a corporate relay team. 

Working in a 9am-6pm work environment can be stressful. Be it corporates or startups. Employers want their teams to be healthy. And employees want to live a healthy life.¬†
The mismatch is in expectations.

Most employers over complicate employee wellness by pushing for programs that don't sync with everyone. But sometimes the biggest impact is driven by doing simple things. 

At Zerodha & Rainmatter playing sports is an anchor that has worked well.
Not just evangelising it but participation from top leadership to everyone in the company. 

For those interested how we do this internally. This is a link to the forum where we discussed everything from event planning, creating a team, training and more. We had three teams and everyone met each other only at the event :) 

Link: https://lnkd.in/giV8PgBA

The upside is, now we have more folks doing events for running, triathlons, obstacle racing and more. There are groups playing some sport every weekend. And all this without any complicated employee wellness program. 
People just talk to each other, signup events and show up to the start line. 

Becoming a healthy company is not an event.
It's a process.
comments:
This is a encouraging to see how the leadership at Zerodha and Rainmatter brings impact in the company's culture towards health and wellness. 

We at Home Fit India are providing the tools for consistent and convenient fitness for working professionals like you. 

May it be sport or general fitness, our focus is to help people involve in strength training and improve strength, endurance, sports performance or efficiency at workplace. 
The five components of Fitness can be achieved conveniently when you have the tools at affordable fees. 
Sriram Chidambaram Dilip Kumar

This thread is pure gold https://lnkd.in/giV8PgBA 

Very proud of you Dilip Kumar :)
This is so heartening to see. And here we have people in academia who look down upon sporting activities.
I love the thought of Mr Nithin Kamath for being fit while working , he is leading by examples

Good to see you Dilip Kumar and your teams participate at IRONMAN INDIA and the Corporate Relay Challenge in Goa. We have created that to encourage more people to take up the relay option and hoping that in turn gets them going towards their health and fitness journey. We are planning to launch a solution in the next few days to facilitate the creation of a relay team across and very encouraging to see what you are promoting within Zerodha and Rainmatter.
Well said Dilip Kumar üëèüèΩüëèüèΩ
Great to see how Zerodha & Rainmatter have made it a part of their culture. Kudos to Dilip Kumar and the team for leading by example!
It's truly refreshing to see how Zerodha & Rainmatter have embraced a simple yet effective approach to employee wellness.
Amazing..

It's wonderful to see how Zerodha & Rainmatter prioritize employee wellness through a simple yet effective approach like sports participation.

Building a healthy company culture is indeed an ongoing journey, and the camaraderie and motivation that come from participating in events together can make a significant difference. 

Kudos to Nithin, Vishnu, and you for crossing that IronMan finish line as a corporate relay team! üèä‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüö¥‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüí™

A good start, well done, and thanks for sharing. 

 However, why do people always think workplace wellness programs are centered on fitness/sports or diet? 

A quick reminder here; there are 8 pillars of wellness in which physical well-being is just one. Also, there are numerous markers of workplace psychological health and safety. 

So, because not all needs will be met, not all measures can be funded and not all employers have the patience, there is always a need for a targeted workplace wellness program that will address these key issues backed by positive ROI or VOI or other KPIs.

Corroborating your last paragraph; becoming a healthy company can never be an event (like a lavish Christmas party in the name of team bondingü§£). It's definitely a process that cannot be circumvented.
Arun Kumar Mishra

Agree completely on the top down approach and play. And you guys do it so well from what I have seen and heard. 

But I wouldn‚Äôt call all this pure/full Employee Wellness or Health (rather Holistic Health). It‚Äôs a good base, a springboard. But there are other higher levels to be reached. Wishing you guys the very best in the #Process.
Great initiative
Well done Dilip!

I led a health and wellness corporate program while I was in an IT job as an initiative in the past (employee base was around 2000+). 

Despite doing many programs across the year to serve employees from all corners of life with a lot of flexibility to ensure the programs and the benefits reached a maximum number of employees, we saw that only 20% of employees were taking a personal interest in leveraging the programs to help them improve their health and wellness. 

While opening up channels like these to encourage employees to operate by themselves is a great idea, I personally feel, we could do so much in this space to especially move the "larger employee group who don't do a lot about their personal health". 

I believe educating them about what health should mean to them, is far more important as a first step before we did a lot as an execution step in my humble view. 

Cheers to what you guys are doing at Rainmatter and Zerodha, Dilip Kumar

Very well said, Dilip‚Ä¶..and I mention in my talks at Indian School of Business to both budding and existing managers, Sports actually enhances Competitiveness in professional life so beneficial to both organisations & employees. This is something which has come out from research done globally.
I love how Zerodha & Rainmatter prioritize employee wellness by keeping it simple and promoting sports. It's great to see the positive impact it has on everyone.
Becoming a healthy company is not an event but a Process! Very Truly said, Dilip.
Fantastic !!

Becoming a healthy company is not an event.
It's a process

---> And it's a NECESSITY!!!

Love this photo! It reminds me my first NY Marathon in 2017 :)

Happy Saturday, Dilip Kumar!!
The last 2 lines sum this up Dilip.

Thank you for sharing this authentic perspective on employee wellness. Your experience shows that it need not be complex or programmatic. Often, the most powerful enabler is leadership participation and grassroots peer support.
By walking the talk and championing sports yourself, you've organically cultivated a culture where employees feel genuinely motivated to pursue fitness as part of work life. Enabling discussions, coordination, and crossover between various activity groups encourages camaraderie and normalization at scale.
This sets in motion a flywheel effect on wellbeing - as more employees share their journeys, inspiration passes on virally while hesitation reduces. Over time, the ecosystem around health goals, be it participating in marathons or something else entirely, starts thriving.
It's about sparking inspiration, not enforcing mandates. And you've found an excellent way to do so in a startup environment by using participation in sports as that cultural catalyst. My appreciation for you demystifying wellness - for highlighting how empowering employees to drive initiatives themselves can make companies both healthier and happier.
üëèüôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è..Mr.Dilip Kumar and Your Team..and as they say.." Life is a process of becoming..a combination of states we have to go through.."üôè ....ü¶ãüå∏....

text:
600 gold medals ü•á . Olympian. Now an entrepreneur. 

This is a fascinating conversation of how a young girl who dreaded swimming went on to win 600+ gold medals and represented India in Olympics.

In this podcast, I‚Äôm talking to Nisha Millet. An Arjuna award winner, she has won¬†numerous domestic & international events. Was the only woman in the 2000 olympics swim team from India. Now a mother of two and an entrepreneur. 

In this podcast we discussed:
- How parents can play a role in creating future olympians.
- The importance of sports & fitness in the personal development of a child.¬†
- How professional athletes train and manage life.¬†
- Her comeback and challenges post retirement from professional swimming. ¬†
- Overcoming mental health challenges.¬†

text:
Startups building for health X Rainmatter

This is a new podcast series to explore conversations with startups and their founders reimagining the business of health, fitness & nutrition.

India has massive health problems. Physical & mental health , nutrition and more. Lifestyles diseases have collectively affected over 400 million Indians across age groups. And we need entrepreneurs to solve for these problems. Not one but many should attempt.

In this series, the conversations will be to explore what these entrepreneurs are building and why it's important. 

In the first episode, i'm joined by Adnan Adeeb, Co-founder of Spectacom Global. The company behind Devils Circuit, Bunkerfit and GetmyBIB.
Listen to the full episode on 
Youtube: https://lnkd.in/gSuMSs3b
Spotify: https://lnkd.in/gNxwDYGu
Apple podcast: https://lnkd.in/gFnHQVSB

Adnan and Zeba are building an ecosystem of fitness and sporting assets to make staying fit fun and exciting for people of all age groups.

We discuss the founding story , how they got the first 100 participants for their first race, the near closure of the company and how the team revived and scaled back post pandemic, the unknowns of sports business in India, transition from a physical experience product to a platform company. And the new stuff they are building to redefinine fitness entertainment.

If you participate in any of the Devil Circuit race, the war cry #booyah will reverberate in your head for next few days üòä

posted_at: {'date': '2023-08-15 07:29:00', 'relative': '2 years ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1692077340339}
text:
As long i live, i will play and win‚Äù

That‚Äôs Bhagwani Devi.¬†
A 95-year-old athlete from Delhi ‚ú® 

She won three gold medals for India at the World Masters Athletics Indoor Championships at Poland. ü•á 

Not just in one sports. But three different sports- 60mtr running, shot put and discus throw.

After the championship she said ‚ÄúAs long i live, i will play and win‚Äù

She was not an athlete in her younger days. 
Had hardships all through her growing years.¬†
Lost husband & one son in her 30‚Äôs.¬†
Worked at farm to earn a living.

Started playing sports at the young age of 94 encouraged by her grandson Vikas Dagar‚Äîa national para-athlete.

Training at this age is not easy.¬†But she now has a competent team that manages all aspects of her strength, nutrition & fitness.

Sport is a great way to stay healthy.¬†
Find what is fun to you. 
Makes you move. 
And you enjoy the most. 

Bhagwani Devi found the athlete in her in 90‚Äôs.
I found mine in my mid 30‚Äôs.¬†
Good luck to finding the athlete in you!
comments: Awesome

text:
Everyone has a reason to race.
We all need to find that reason.
At work or on the field.

A few years after the death of her husband, Marjorie was inspired to run her first marathon. After seven months of training, this 81-year-old ran in the NYC Marathon as a dedication to her husband.

She trained for it.
At an age, when most will write her off.

The marathon doesn't owe you anything.
When you run a marathon, you run against your own fears.
Not against the other runners.

Mother of Two. An Ultramarathoner.
And perhaps the fastest CFO in India.

In this eighth episode of "The Other Side", I'm talking with Rashmi Mohanty who is currently the CFO of SBI Card. An endurance athlete who runs 100km races to explore her mental & physical limits.

In this podcast we unpack her other side:
- Her journey from a college athlete to corporate boardroom.
- Revisiting her passion for sports & fitness after becoming a mother of two toddlers.
- Chasing peak athletic pursuits in her 50's.
- Balancing training between family & professional commitments.
- Experiences of running some of the toughest races in the world.
- Toolkit to overcome challenges faced by women in corporate & sports.

There are a lot of takeways from this conversation and I hope it inspires you to get out and start building your other side soon

text:
GOALS
They look far and hazy unless you keep chasing them. 
Every day, every week, every month.


In 2020, I set a goal to run a Sub 3hr marathon. 
For 4months, I was chasing this goal. It was up on my wall üòä 
To become Sub 3 marathoner.

And every week, I got two inch closer.

I‚Äôll wake up and stare at the wall reminiscing all the past training and before going to bed muster whatever left for the next day.

Marathon training is just learning to be bored while you're hurting. 

Did i meet my goal? ...Yes, I finished 2:59:52 üòå 
But those 16 weeks changed me a lot.
as an entrepreneur,
as a colleague,
as a husband,
as a friend,
and as an athlete.

There are maybe 100 men in India who can run Sub3hr marathon.
I'm one of them.
Today a 2:55:58 Marathoner.
Head high, heart full.

Everyone teaches motivation. But no one learns discipline.
Motivation is in abundance. Discipline is scarce. 

The progress in your goals is the gap between your desire and commitment. 

This is the exact training plan i followed to become a Sub3hr marathoner üòä üëá 


I host a podcast called  "The Other Side‚Äù 
Video https://lnkd.in/gxHbvfJd
Audio https://pod.link/dilip

text:
‚ÄúAs long i live, i will play and win‚Äù

That‚Äôs Bhagwani Devi.¬†
A 95-year-old athlete from Delhi ‚ú® 

She won three gold medals for India at the World Masters Athletics Indoor Championships at Poland. ü•á 

Not just in one sports. But three different sports- 60mtr running, shot put and discus throw.

After the championship she said ‚ÄúAs long i live, i will play and win‚Äù

She was not an athlete in her younger days. 
Had hardships all through her growing years.¬†
Lost husband & one son in her 30‚Äôs.¬†
Worked at farm to earn a living.

Started playing sports at the young age of 94 encouraged by her grandson Vikas Dagar‚Äîa national para-athlete.

Training at this age is not easy.¬†But she now has a competent team that manages all aspects of her strength, nutrition & fitness.

Sport is a great way to stay healthy.¬†
Find what is fun to you. 
Makes you move. 
And you enjoy the most. 

Bhagwani Devi found the athlete in her in early 90‚Äôs.
I found mine in my mid 30‚Äôs.¬†
Good luck to finding the athlete in you!

She is an excellent example of how we can all find joy and purpose in staying active and pursuing our interests.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-02-04 11:52:37', 'relative': '2 years ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1675507957897}
text:
Priyanka Gupta asked me why the heck i'm so keen to prioritise fitness. And it took 60 mins to explain the "Why". 

I hope our conversation is useful in some way. 

Please remember, becoming unhealthy is not an event. It is a process. Like a plane crash, becoming unhealthy is rarely caused by one thing going wrong. Usually, it is a series of ignorance‚Äî lack of physical exercise, compromising on sleep, food choices & stress.  All these will interact and then compound. I realised the process late in my life though. 

It's very rare to meet people who are driven by genuine curiosity and passion to learn a new skill. Priyanka is one of them. 

Link to the full podcast in the comment section below.

text:
Nithin Kamath invites competition. But not in stock brokerage. 


You should watch the full episode to understand why every entrepreneur should also be a sports person. All the guest i spoke with on my podcast have this common trait of playing some sport. Why?

Ofcourse you gain fitness.

But there are benefits beyond that. What are they?

- Develops a mindset to deal with pressure and competition.¬†
- Builds mental models for proactive thinking and problem solving.¬†
- Learning from injuries will prepare you to handle failures.¬†
- Builds mental toughness. Every game starts with zero.¬†
- Teamwork. Giving up the ‚ÄòMe‚Äô for the ‚ÄòWe‚Äô.
- Sometimes playing defense can be a superpower.¬†
- Everyone has a shelf life. Nithin calls it the ‚Äòenergy efficiency‚Äô 

What sport do you play that has benefitted you the most? 

#fitness  #podcast #entrepreneur #startup #sports #health

A poignant reminder to everyone. Watch this now. You could be a founder, C level executive, manager, team leader or just getting into professional world. 

Recalling the evocative thoughts shared by Nithin & Rajiv in the podcast earlier https://lnkd.in/g5yPHgC9

Nithin - ¬†"How you take care of your health post 35 is what determines quality of life post 60. Backcasting is a powerful tool. Start working on it today."

Rajiv - "If the avg lifespan is 80, after 37.5 years of age you‚Äôre no longer a time billionaire. You don‚Äôt have more than billion seconds to live. That‚Äôs the time wealth everyone has got. Regardless what your net worth is or assets you have made.¬†Invest your time on your health."

Third episode of the podcast releases end of this week. 

Video credits to Heart & Stroke foundation, Canada.
